TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them, for cost saving reasons only, on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra Bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senators in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jones (from 95 citizens) and Panizza (from 2,959 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: In-vitro Fertilisation Patients: Medicare Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows a request for Medicare benefits for in-vitro-fertilisation for the medical treatment of infertile couples.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled grant Medicare benefits for in vitro-fertilisation, IVF, for the medical treatment of infertile couples. 1 in 10 Australian couples are infertile and unable to conceive and carry a baby to birth. Having a family is one of the most fundamental and rewarding aspects of life and benefits the community as a whole. IVF is an established and proven treatment for infertility. There are existing mechanisms to regulate and control IVF, including the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Reproductive Technology Accreditation Committee. Currently IVF patients pay up to $1500 per treatment cycle for IVF out of their own pockets. This means that some couples who need IVF to help them establish their own family do not have access. We request that Medicare funding be granted for IVF for the treatment of infertility.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That it be recognised the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill is a public, legal acknowledgement that Australians who are non-aboriginal do not have sovereignty in their own country.

2. That the Australian people are opposed to the idea of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Australian people who are non-aboriginal and those who are aboriginal, and the Government has no mandate or authority to pursue it.
3. That the proposed legislation and treaty
will damage Australia's position under international law and in any conflict,
will cause distrust and conflict between our aboriginal population (1%) and the non-aboriginal population (99%),
will extend aboriginal land rights, contrary to the wishes of the Australian people,
will not be acceptable to the aboriginal people themselves,
will solve none of the problems of aboriginal people who need housing, health services, education and employment.

That therefore, the Senate reject absolutely the announced proposals for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, and the negotiation of a Treaty, compact or makarrata between the Commonwealth and aboriginal people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution: Proposed Changes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. the right of the people of a country to make law independent of politicians should be a basic and independent right;
2. consequently there is an urgent need for constitutional reforms.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
support the Constitutional Alteration (Electors Initiative) 1987 Bill to alter the constitution so as to vest in the electors power to propose laws and to approve or disapprove such proposed laws.
and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The costs of raising children are rising and the value of government provided economic assistance to families is declining.
Families raising children are providing a vital function to society and are deserving of government provided economic assistance.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
1. Restore family allowance payments to their 1976 real money value.
2. Provide for the regular and automatic indexation of family allowance payments.
3. Increase the value of the Dependant Spouse Rebate to $1851 per annum and convert it to a cash payment given directly to the non-income earning spouse.
4. Amend the Family Income Supplement Scheme so that its value is increased, its eligibility provisions widened and its withdrawal provisions eased.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by Cobalt 60, caesium 137, caesium 134 or any machine sources.
That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted by State Governments.

We request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ban the importation of any radioactive substances, or machinery for the purposes of food irradiation; disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in this country; ban the irradiation of food in this country; and also ban the importation of food treated by irradiation.

We ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, request the Government to withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, shall ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Preservation of the Environment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of The Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

But for a High Court decision narrowly favouring the Federal Government, 20,000 years old archaeological cave sites near the Franklin River, Tasmania, would have been destroyed, like a United Kingdom Government unable to stop a Wiltshire authority from clearing Stonehenge for a freeway. Constitutional protection for historical and environmental assets is needed.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to hold a Referendum to amend the Constitution so that:

The Federal Government has the bounden constitutional duty, which any citizen may legally require it to perform and a right superior to state and local governments, to set above the commercial advantage of one generation, protect and restore all we hold in trust for the future-
Including relics, sites, features, areas, wildlife, buildings or things of Aboriginal and other historical, cultural, architectural, scientific, aesthetic, ecological or environmental importance and-

To care for the maintenance of the balance of nature, manage land, marine and atmospheric use so as to avoid their degradation and act nationally and internationally in any matter seen as related to these including-

To prevent military and commercial use of uranium and derivatives, beach and related mining; to preserve Heritage Areas, The Great Barrier Reef Region at least as originally defined in the 1975 Act and extended into Torres Strait.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sporting, Cultural and Community Groups: Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned:
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Relocation of Transylvanian Village Dwellers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

A decision has been made by the Roumanian Government to raze villages where there are fewer than 5000 inhabitants. This ``decision'' is against the wishes of these people and as such it is a complete denial of their basic human rights. This would result in a total cultural genocide of regions which have a history dating back before the middle ages. It is imperative for us to preserve the cultural heritage of all peoples, and we the undersigned therefore request your support and immediate action to halt particularly this, and any other action which destroys valuable living cultures.
And your 5247 petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sale of Land in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We the people of Australia/Australian citizens are concerned with the way our nation is being sold from underneath our feet;
the future generations of Australians must have protected the right to own land in this country; they must be able to afford and to buy land in their own country;
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
make it mandatory that only Australian citizens can buy and sell land in Australia
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation, as I claim to have been misrepresented.
—Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

—So much has been misreported about my domestic circumstances in the last few days that I think I must use this forum to set the record straight. First, let me state quite clearly and unequivocally that I have never been an applicant for public housing. Like many other tenants on the Glebe Estate, I am there as an historical anomaly. If the church had not sold its property in 1975, I would not be the subject of vicious attacks by the New South Wales Government today.

SPEECH.PARA: It is understandable that there should be considerable resentment towards a senator occupying a Housing Commission home. I am, of course, not the only one. That housing is a major crisis in contemporary Australian society is an indictment of our governments. When I first went to live in the Glebe Estate 20 years ago it was as a student and I was a private tenant of the Anglican Church. The housing was substandard, the rents were low, but it was an interesting community of students and locals. In 1975, the Church sold the Estate of 600 dwellings to the Whitlam Government, which established the Estate for public housing, as distinct from welfare housing. Tom Uren, then Minister for Urban and Regional Development and author of the Estate, intended that the Estate should contain a social mix of workers, professionals and those on social security of one kind or another. The idea was to establish a viable community, and that has proven to be a successful social experiment.

I, along with many other residents, did not welcome the news that the Federal Government had transferred the Estate to the New South Wales Housing Commission in 1985. Nonetheless, I remained on the Estate because the quality of the housing did not concern me that much, and the rent certainly suited a freelance editor, film-maker and political activist. I was not making a great deal of money. I had no assets, but I did make some good films and contributed my labours freely to what I believed were worthwhile projects, including a campaign to free three men unjustly convicted of a crime they did not commit. The films won prizes and the men were released from jail.

Some 18 months ago my circumstances changed and I entered full-time employment. I informed the Housing Commission and paid the full rent for my flat as assessed by the Commission. I repeat: I was not a public housing applicant; never. I spent money on renovating the flat, which had not been touched for 10 years by the Commission or the Federal Government. And I did not move. It did not, quite frankly, occur to me to move. I regarded that place as my home and I was prepared to pay the rents set by the landlord. Similarly, when I became a senator just a mere two months ago I would not have considered moving from the place I regarded as home even if I had had time to think about it. Call this naivety, but call it no more than that.

It is clear that the New South Wales Minister for Housing, Joe Schipp, has tried to blame me for the problems of the homeless in New South Wales when his Government is decimating public housing in the inner city areas of Sydney by selling off Mort Bay, the Raleigh Park Estate at Kensington, the Crown Street Women's Hospital site and others, which in all would provide homes for 2,000 families. If Mr Schipp is so concerned about the homeless, why does he not give over a room in his house to some homeless person, and ask his mates in government to do the same? If Mr Schipp tries to evict me--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. Apart from the fact that Senator Dunn ought to read the Standing Orders and know how to conduct herself, she sought leave to make a personal explanation, not to debate the housing policies of a Minister in the New South Wales Government. I ask that leave be now withdrawn.

—Senator Dunn, you must deal with the personal circumstances surrounding your housing, not the housing policies of a government. You should be making a personal explanation about your own personal situation.

—I understand that, Mr President. If Mr Schipp tries to evict me, it is clear that he will also have to evict 22,000 other people. Yesterday he increased my rent by 160 per cent. This means I will be paying $200 a week for a run-down, one bedroom flat in Glebe. He backdated payments to July. By contrast, other well-off tenants will now be asked to pay a 50 per cent increase from next April. It is clear that he is penalising me for the poor management and inefficiencies of the Commission. Let me conclude by saying that Mr Schipp has stirred up a hornet's nest with the housing issue and he may well get stung.

Since the deregulation of the industry at the beginning of 1988, oil producers have proven to be quick to develop new markets and innovative marketing techniques. In this way they have been able to maximise the value of their output, both to themselves and the nation. However, as a result of these developments certain types of crude oil transactions have occurred which are not strictly covered by the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act 1987, since these transactions were not envisaged when the Act was passed.

The principal purpose of this Bill, which is largely of a technical nature, is to amend the 1987 Act to provide the Minister with additional powers to fix, for the purpose of excise determination, prices for certain types of crude oil transactions. Such transactions include sales where a quantity of crude oil is disposed of either by exchange, having the oil converted to products which are then sold or by any means other than direct sale for example, by barrier.

Commonwealth excise on crude oil production is estimated at $1.4 million in 1988-89. This bill is essential to ensure that excise on the transactions described is assessed on a fair and accurate basis. In addition, the Bill will allow crude oil producers the greatest possible flexibility in the use of marketing techniques.

The speech read as follows-

This Bill proposes amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921, to give effect to the Government's decision announced as part of the May 1988 economic statement to remove the exemption from liability for excise duty presently afforded to government business enterprises, and to incorporate into that Act various excise tariff proposals tabled in this Parliament during the last sittings.
Removal of Excise Duty Exemption from Government Business Enterprises

The amendment relating to government business enterprises removes from 1 July 1989 the exemption from liability for excise duty on goods which are used by those agencies and budget-funded authorities.

Honourable senators will recall that the exemption from liability for customs duty on goods imported by these bodies was removed as a result of the Government's decision in the May 1987 economic statement. It is the intention of this Bill that all such Commonwealth agencies which are now liable for customs duty on their imports will also be liable for excise duty from 1 July 1989 on domestically produced excisable goods which they use.
Government business enterprises which are currently subject to customs duties but exempt from excise duties include Telecom and Australia Post.

The proposed amendment in clause 5 of this Bill will rectify the anomalous situation whereby goods acquired by these and other like agencies can attract different indirect tax treatment depending on whether they are imported or produced domestically.

The removal of these excise exemptions is consistent with the Government's moves to improve the efficiency of government business enterprises by placing them on a more commercial footing. The May 1988 economic statement endorsed the general principle that these enterprises should be exposed to the same taxes and charges as private businesses. In line with this endorsement the timing of the removal of a number of remaining tax exemptions attracted by government business enterprises, including excise duty, was announced in the May 1988 economic statement.

It is proposed that by-laws will be made under the Excise Act 1901 prescribing an identical list of exempt agencies in relation to excise duty as has been promulgated for customs duty by by-laws made under the Customs Act 1901.
Liquefied Petroleum Gas

The excise duty for naturally occurring LPG is adjusted six-monthly on 1 April and 1 October each year in accordance with the Government's LPG excise policy announced in April 1980. The excise rate is calculated as 60 per cent of the amount by which the realised price for naturally occurring LPG exceeds $147 a tonne. The realised price is based on the weighted average of the prices received from exports and local sales of LPG during the immediately preceding six months.

Under the petroleum excise arrangements introduced from 1 July 1987, LPG produced from onshore fields is exempt from excise, so the excise now only applies to offshore fields-that is, Bass Strait. No excise is payable on refinery-produced LPG.

Clause 3 of the Bill will amend the excise rate with effect from 1 April 1988, from $13.21 to $15.39 a kilolitre, an increase of $2.18 from the previous rate set on 1 October 1987. The increase reflects the higher export prices obtained for LPG over the six months to March 1988.
Aviation Kerosene-Avtur

Clause 4 of the Bill will remove the excise duty on aviation kerosene with effect from 1 July 1988, by reducing the rate of excise from $0.16087 per litre to zero. This adjustment stems from the Government's decision in the May 1988 economic statement to discontinue the excise on aviation kerosene and substitute an enroute charge levied by the Civil Aviation Authority. The authority commenced levying the charge on 1 July 1988, the same day the excise was discontinued.

This measure gives partial effect to the funding element of the Government's decision to transfer the functional responsibility for the provision of air traffic control, flight advisory services, communications, navigation and surveillance systems and rescue and firefighting services to the Civil Aviation Authority. Hitherto, revenue from excise tariff duties on aviation kerosene have been attributed to the aviation industry for cost recovery purposes. For purposes of aviation cost recovery calculations, aviation fuel excise revenues had generally been set against the cost of providing airways enroute facilities and services and system overhead costs.

With the transfer to the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) of the responsibility for the provision of airways enroute facilities and services from 1 July 1988, the Government reviewed the funding arrangements for the new authority and decided that the CAA would introduce domestic enroute charges for its services in place of budget revenues from excise duties on aviation kerosene and departure tax. Clause 4 of this Bill therefore abolishes excise duties on avtur in accordance with those arrangements. These changed arrangements ensure that the CAA is fully responsible and accountable for the provision and pricing of its commercial airways services. The new enroute charges of that authority represent a more appropriate and efficient user-pays basis for these services.
Financial Impact Statement
(a) Government business enterprises-removal of excise exemption.
There are no direct financial implications for the 1988-89 year, as the measure does not come into operation until 1 July 1989.
Additional excise receipts in 1989-90 are estimated at $25 million.
(b) Liquefied petroleum gas:
The 1 April 1988 increase in the excise rate for naturally occurring LPG is estimated to result in an increase of $3.4 million in excise receipts in 1988-89;
(c) Aviation kerosene (Avtur)
The removal of the excise duty on aviation kerosene will result in a decrease in excise revenue of $190 million in the 1988-89 financial year.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the determination of the Pathology Services Table contained in Determination PST2/1988 and made under section 4a of the Health Insurance Act 1973, be disallowed.

We come before the Senate to examine once again changes in Government health policy and, in particular, the financing of health services. The Government has demonstrated an incapacity to manage the financial aspects of its medical and health policies in a competent fashion. In October 1987 the Pathology Services Advisory Committee (PSAC) was established. Its brief was to provide for a more rapid and flexible procedure for reviewing and revising the pathology services table and the associated fees for Medicare rebate purposes. However, there was an unusual element to the way in which the PSAC was established and given its authority. That unusual element was that when it made recommendations to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), the Minister had the choice simply to accept the recommendations in total or to reject them in total. He did not have available a discretion to vary the recommendations or, indeed, a discretion to accept some and reject others.

On 31 July 1988 the Pathology Services Advisory Committee made and forwarded recommendations to the Minister for Community Services and Health about the pathology services table and associated fees for Medicare benefit purposes. The motivation behind the PSAC review which resulted in the recommendations was to rationalise the pathology services table. The published PSAC recommendation states in paragraphs 4.6 and 4.7:

The recommended table represents an attempt to deal with all the identified problems in a manner which also provides incentives for pathology providers and referees to be more thoughtful about the way they order pathology and use the pathology services table . . . The recommended table is designed to eliminate the necessity for repetition of item numbers within single patient encounters.

That may be all very well, but the recommendations and the scale of fees attached have led to a potentially disastrous situation for the providers of pathology services, both in the private and public sectors.

I will examine briefly the recommendations of the Advisory Committee in regard to the financial impact of its proposals. I turn to the statement of reasons by the Committee for the recommendation dated 31 July 1988, which was made under section 78c (1) of the Health Insurance Act 1973. Page 12 of the Committee's report states:
The basis upon which fees have been fixed in the recommended Table is in conformity with an objective that the total Medicare benefit cost not be increased as a result of the revision undertaken.
An effect of the recommended changes to both items and fees has been that it has not been possible to calculate the cost impact of the recommended table.
The Committee then goes on to say subsequently:
Consideration was given to the preparation of a statistical model of incidence of items and benefits payments. This proved to be impossible.
Further on page 13 of the report the Committee states:

When a similar exercise, that is to say essentially a modelling exercise, was attempted within some private practices variable results were obtained due to differing tests combinations. An overall reduction of 5 to 8 per cent was found but the statistical sampling was not large or widespread enough to give clear indications in respect to the true financial impact.

There are three elements that arise from that analysis of the financial impact statement contained within the Committee's report: firstly, that the provisions would be revenue neutral-that is to say that they would not significantly vary the overall cost to the Medicare system; secondly, that it had not been found possible by the Committee to undertake a modelling procedure which would allow it to make a calculation on best available evidence of the impact of these changes on pathology services provided in either the public or private sector; and thirdly, that using such techniques as were available to it and as were considered appropriate by the Committee, it was believed that an overall reduction in the order of 5 to 8 per cent would be achieved in terms of the Medicare rebate payments and thereby indirectly in terms of the rebates and income available to the pathology practitioners.

This figure gained some degree of credence. It was used as the basis of statements made on behalf of the Minister for Community Services and Health and indeed, the Budget Papers contain an indication that it was expected that something in the order of $11m would be saved by these moves, that representing about a 2.2 per cent reduction in overall costs of pathology services. We have, quite clearly, an acceptance of that round figure of 5 per cent or so both by the Committee and by spokesmen on behalf of the Minister. That is reflected in the Budget Papers which were presented just a couple of months ago.

However, when one undertakes a detailed examination of the proposed changes, one sees that 5 to 8 per cent becomes absolutely impossible to sustain. It is quite clear that the loss which will be suffered by practitioners in the private pathology sector could be in the order of 15 to 20 per cent and, in the public pathology sector, up to 30 per cent. What happened was that those who were most directly concerned with this determination-they included the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia (RCPA) and the Australian Association of Pathology Practices (AAPP)-undertook a modelling exercise. Their modelling exercise was verified by Coopers and Lybrand W. D. Scott and the Department of Community Services and Health. Their model indicated quite clearly that the adoption of the new scale of fees would result in reductions of private pathology incomes of 15 to 20 per cent and reductions of public pathology incomes of up to 30 per cent. This is late in the day. The new schedule of fees is due to commence today. One of the difficulties that have been encountered is that, despite the repeated requests made by both the Royal College and the Association of Pathology Practices to the Minister for some deferral of the commencement of these arrangements, such a deferral has not been possible, or has not been conceded as being possible by the Government.

The Government has recognised that the scale of fees which was proposed is inappropriate. It understands that it is facing a major problem in this regard. In a press statement by the Chairperson of the Pathology Services Advisory Committee, His Honour Mr Justice Munro, dated 20 September 1988, he indicates that a full review of the Medicare pathology services table will be undertaken immediately and that this follows the interim revision of the table recently completed and now put into effect and subject to this disallowance motion.

It is quite clearly recognised by most people in the field that this scale of fees will have the impact which I have mentioned and is likely to be extremely threatening to the continuation of pathology services, particularly those in the private sector. An article which appeared in the Australian Financial Review on 21 October 1988 states:

A `revenue neutral' decision to halve the number of items on Medicare's pathology schedule has threatened the financial viability of public and private practices and unwittingly saved the Federal Government $100m.

The article goes on to detail the sort of information which I have put to the Senate this morning. It is quite clear that there is a widespread acceptance of the fact that this schedule is inappropriate. For a number of private practitioners it will be a fatal blow to the continuation of their practices. It will not simply be those in the private sector who will be affected. A number of people in the public sector also will be affected. I intend to refer to a couple of matters in that regard. Firstly, I will give an example of the impact which this change of fees will have on one pathology service. I refer to the pathology service which takes place at the Taylor Square Private Clinic in Sydney. The Taylor Square Private Clinic, which is run by Dr Basil Donovan, who is the President of the Venereology Association of Australia and one of the most eminent practitioners in the field of venereology and sexually transmitted disease management and indeed, in terms of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome, provides a pathology service which is likely to be destroyed if this scale of fees is allowed to continue. Dr Donovan wrote to the Minister for Community Services and Health on 1 October 1988, and I propose to read his letter. He said:
Dear Dr Blewett
I have to appeal to you in the strongest terms to defer the above measures.
That is to say, the rebate system to be introduced on 1 November. He continued:

This Clinic could not survive the resultant 32% drop in gross practice income, including a 60% drop in the rebate for standard sexually transmissible disease . . . testing: we are already at the limit of our working overdraft. In part this is because of the change in practice profile due to a longstanding commitment to AIDS prevention and treatment, and also as a result of other reductions (in the recent past) to Medicare rebates.

The outcome of closure of this Clinic would be the loss of this state's only recognisable private consultancy service for the referral of complicated STDs and the abandonment of the 600-700 AIDS and HIV antibody positive patients who receive regular monitoring and management of intercurrent medical problems (including terminal care) through the Clinic. I can only predict that this would cause considerable distress to our clientele, be detrimental to the public health and directly cost the public purse more money as these people would be managed much more expensively in the public sector.

As our regular clientele becomes increasingly unwell, and go onto sickness benefits or invalid pensions, we find that over 50% of visits are now bulk-billed. The personal income of the doctors in this Clinic are now well below those of our counterparts in the public clinics. Some of our counterparts in the United States, who were pioneers in the description of the AIDS epidemic, have been bankrupted by their involvement.

If our situation sounds strange it is because, in contrast to Britain and New Zealand, STD medicine (or Venereology) is not a recognised medical speciality in Australia. While we function as specialists, with all of the ensuing practice overheads, we do not receive similar remuneration. The Clinic has to be `propped up' by a pathology service for both economic and quality control reasons.

Our selective use of the service however provides economies for Medicare and supports the salaries of our specialist STD nurse counsellors and the maintenance of clinical skills, infection control practices, inner city commercial rentals, etc, forced on us by our major involvement in HIV medicine.

Dr Donovan concludes his letter by drawing the attention of the Minister to an article published in the Medical Journal of Australia about the clinic's outstanding record, and record of success, in the management of patients with HIV infection. That is simply one example of a small but important clinic in Sydney whose work will be destroyed, whose financial viability will be destroyed, and whose long term continuation will be made impossible if this scale of fees is allowed to continue.

The Government of New South Wales is particularly concerned about this matter. On 31 October the Hon. Peter Collins, the Minister for Health in New South Wales, wrote to Dr David Kindon, the Secretary of the Australian Association of Pathology Practices. Minister Collins says in his letter, in part:

I have noted your concerns, many of which are shared by the Department of Health, NSW, and a number of public hospitals in the state. You may be interested to know that the Secretary of the Department of Health, NSW, wrote to his counterpart in the Commonwealth on 20th October 1988 to express misgivings about fee levels in the Schedule and the timetable for its implementation.

Quite apart from the potential reduction in fee revenue flowing from the new Schedule, the Department is extremely concerned about the limited time available to adjust hospitals' computer billing programs (less than 5 weeks). In addition, the presence of definitions that are unclear, the application of special conditions, (e.g. time limits on tests) and the existence of several anomalies in the interim Schedule, combine to create a complex new charging system. The Department's Information Service Division has estimated that it will take at least 2 months to alter the current hospital billing programs to implement the new Schedule.

Whilst the NSW Government supports measures that are designed to remove abuses of Medicare, such measures should not financially penalise the legitimate and high quality work performed by this State's hospital-based Group Pathology Services. Accordingly, I am forwarding a copy of this letter to Dr. Blewett. I have requested that he defer the introduction of the new Schedule until discussions can be completed on its interpretation and until the administrative machinery for its implementation can be finalised.

Mr Collins is making the same point, on behalf of the group pathology services which operate within the New South Wales public hospital system, as the point which was made by Dr Donovan and by others in regard to private pathology services. What we have is a whole series, once again, of what might be referred to as unintended consequences. Unfortunately, that is somewhat typical of the way in which the Government manages its cost cutting exercises within the health sector. The new rules are complex, they are difficult to administer, and they are in no way capable of being able to gauge accurately the appropriate level of patient rebate. Some of the rebates will in fact be cut quite substantially. For instance, in the case of some immunology services, the reduction is to be in the order of 50 per cent. As I said, this is another example of the Hawke Labor Government's approach to cost cutting within medical services.

Honourable senators will undoubtedly recall that we had a lengthy debate over a couple of days in this place about the disallowance of certain regulations made in relation to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS). I, in fact, moved on behalf of the Opposition for the disallowance of the new regulations which would have removed 53 drugs from the PBS schedule and would have put them into a system whereby special authority had to be obtained for their prescription. The Government resisted that move and, with the support of the Australian Democrats, defeated it. That was just a couple of weeks ago. However, within a week or 10 days of that matter being discussed here in Parliament the Government has backtracked and 34 of the 53 drugs, which were the essence of that debate, have now been deleted from the authority system and put back into the situation in which we claim all of the 53 drugs should have been left. That, of course, took place because there was once again a review. The Government undertook on that occasion through the work of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee a re-examination of an earlier determination and ended up scrapping most of the determination.

We see once again that there is to be yet a further review by the Pathology Services Advisory Committee of its initial determination, which is the cause of this disallowance motion. That Committee is to meet again next Friday. It is to review once again the determination in light of all the evidence that has been put before it; the evidence that far from being a 5 to 8 per cent reduction in rebates to pathologists we are talking about anything between 15 and 30 per cent, that it has got the figures wrong, that it has introduced a system which is extraordinarily complicated in an administrative sense in which the groupings of items do not appear to be coherent to those who are most concerned and do not appear to be entirely coherent in the view of the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia and the Australian Association of Pathology Practices.

Once again, the Government is going back to the drawing board. We are saying that this determination, should be disallowed now. Instead of making adjustments from an unsatisfactory position, the current position should be maintained until the new review has looked at all the issues and determined a more appropriate scale of rebates, a more appropriate scale of fees, a more appropriate definition of the items to be covered, of the item numbers and of the groupings of items which are to be provided on the records which will be put forward for rebate purposes. In a press statement issued yesterday the shadow Minister for health, my colleague the honourable member for Tangney, Peter Shack, put forward the Opposition's view in these words:
In short, the Government has made a huge mistake and the financial impact of the new schedule is far more serious than is intended, or the pathologists were led to expect.
Not only that, but the Government has admitted its mistake yet is refusing to delay the implementation of the new schedule.
This attitude is totally consistent with the Government's belligerent stance towards doctors and pharmacists.
It is also in keeping with its cost containment measures currently affecting Medicare rebates for medical services and Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme subsidies.
Calls by the RCPA and the AAPP for the Government to defer the introduction of the new schedule pending its restructuring and re-costing have fallen on deaf ears.

By moving for the disallowance of the Interim Schedule the Opposition is seeking to buy breathing space both for patients who could face extra out of pocket expenses, and for pathology practices threatened with bankruptcy.

In the interests of seeing that patients receive the first class pathology services to which they are entitled the Government must not only admit its mistake, but be willing to go back to the drawing board.
This is not a case of gaps between pathology fees and Medicare rebates resulting from pathologists lifting their charges.

Instead, the Government is creating a gap by withdrawing rebates to the detriment of the provision of effective diagnostic services. Under this schedule there are a number of serious anomalies such as in clinical microbiology where blood culture test rebates will barely cover the cost of culture media for patients with septicaemia.
In the investigation of suspected endocartisis, for example, multiple samples of blood must be collected on sequential days.
But the economic imperatives of the new schedule would be to minimise the number of samples and the use of culture media.
These are just a couple of examples of other undesirable features of the schedule which could be directly prejudicial to good patient care.
If the Government has any commitment at all to seeing the delivery of quality health care it must delay the introduction of the new schedule and address the many serious issues which it raises.

That is the statement of the Opposition's position on this particular matter. We believe that the Government has made a serious mistake. We accept that the Minister for Health had no alternative but to either accept or reject the recommendations of the Committee in toto. We accept that the Committee itself will undertake some revision of this particular matter. We believe that that should take place from the existing position which applied prior to yesterday rather than from the position of the introduction of the new determination which in fact commences today.

May I say that the issues are indeed extremely complicated. May I also concede that there is a need within the health services to minimise the costs in areas such as pathology and pharmaceuticals. Indeed, within the pathology section in particular there is a need to eliminate a number of undesirable practices and rorts, some of which border on the criminal. People will recall that some years ago I spent an hour or so of the Senate's time discussing the affairs of Dr Edelsten, his clinics and the misuse of pathology services for which he was responsible and which were the subject of an investigation by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts under the chairmanship of former Senator Georges. A number of matters including criminal charges flowed from that.

We have never been unwilling to support the Government in steps taken to crack down on illegitimate practices, or rorts of the system or on those elements of the system where cost containment needs to be more effectively policed. This is not one of those situations. This is a situation in which the Government has made a serious error. The Senate has the capacity by disallowing this determination to ensure that that error does not prejudice the good health of the people of Australia. I commend my motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage the Australian Democrats are minded to support the Opposition's move to disallow these regulations. We draw attention again to the two unsatisfactory aspects of the way in which regulations come into existence; namely, that very often they have an effect before the disallowance can be properly debated and, secondly, that one cannot pick and choose in relation to regulations-one has either to disallow in toto or to allow in toto. These matters have put us in a situation in which the schedule will come into existence. As Senator Puplick has pointed out, not only does this involve a change in the fee structure against code numbers which remain unchanged but in this case there is a change in the whole schedule so that pathologists' offices will have to completely reprogram their computers to work to the proposed new fee structure. The sooner this matter is sorted out the better, and for that reason we are minded to bring this matter to a vote quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Puplick indicated in his closing remarks, in the past vast profits have been made in the pathology area of medicine. As one who worked for many years as a pathologist-not in a laboratory providing routine services but in a research capacity, although nonetheless associated with pathologists providing those sorts of services-I know that in the late 1960s and early 1970s when pathology moved from the hand-type laboratory tests, where one used beakers and pipettes and so on, over to the automated tests in which first four, then eight, then 12 and then 24 tests were done on a single sample, the fee schedules remained locked into the earlier methods of conducting these tests and pathologists were really making enormous incomes.

I had friends who went into private pathology who very quickly were working three and four-day weeks because they were embarrassed by the size of their tax bill. That seems now to be well and truly in the past. Pathologists' reimbursements under the schedule of fees have been brought more into line with the actual costs of conducting these tests, and the new schedule would seem to indicate, on the best available evidence, that the reimbursements to pathologists would fall by somewhere between 15 per cent and 18 per cent in an industry which is now, as far as one can judge, well run and, to use the Government's jargon, very competitive.

One other aspect of these regulations which concerns us is the need for a wide ranging review of the provision of medical services generally in this country. We have recently had a debate on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) schedule. In that instance we supported the Government's moves to remove certain drugs from the PBS schedule, but in the course of that debate we pointed out, as did the Opposition, the need for a very wide ranging review of the nature of the medical services and the need to shift the emphasis in those medical services from treatment towards prevention. Immediately after the conclusion of that debate on the disallowance motion on the PBS, we introduced a motion, which unfortunately was not supported by the Opposition, calling for a wide ranging review of the PBS.

If one were to pick up that principle in relation to pathology services-this bears very much on a matter which Senator McLean has raised several times in recent days in the Senate-provision would be made for tests which were carried out by those doctors who were pursuing less usual causes of illness, causes related to potential environmental contamination, stress, obscure sensitivity to environmental agents, particularly toxic agents and the like, some of whom, as we have heard in questions in this place, have been denied the ability to claim reimbursement for those tests. All these matters, I believe, should be thrown back into the melting pot, particularly in view of the increasing cost of the provision of medical services in this country.

I think other senators will have had the experience of being continually exposed to lobbying from groups seeking reimbursement for tests for treatments and the like carried out at vast expense to the public for extremely limited benefit. As a community, and I have made this point before, we should be addressing this problem. We should be opening up to public debate the question of what sorts of medical services we want as a community, how much we are prepared to pay, and how we get the greatest long term benefit to the community for the dollars we spend. I believe a review like that would clearly indicate that an emphasis on the preventive aspects of medicine would be far more beneficial than the present very great emphasis on expenditure on the treatment of those who have already become ill. I think the small amount which is spent on anti-tobacco advertising, for instance, produces a far greater benefit than the treatment of those people who have become ill because of smoking, particularly those who go on to develop malignancy. The cost of those pathology tests spread out over many years is vast indeed. I believe a substantial shift in funds into those preventive areas would see not only a healthier community but also a reduction in the overall costs of medical care in this country.

We simply cannot go on spending more and more money in the medical area. It is a larger and larger percentage of gross national product each year. No doubt the reason that the Government has attempted to reschedule the fee structure for pathologists is related to that issue, as was the restructuring of the schedule for the PBS. However, these things are being done in isolation. They are being done as individual packages. What really is required is a total review, which must necessarily involve the public, of the costs of medical care; of the ways in which we can spend our health care dollar to provide the greatest benefit. Recognising that this set of regulations in relation to the pathology schedule involves a vast and expensive rescheduling of the computers in pathologists' offices, we believe that the sooner this matter is finalised and brought to a vote the better.
