DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX ASSESSMENT (No. 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1988SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 October, on motion by Senator Reynolds:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax Assessment (No. 1) Amendment Bill and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill represent the implementation of the Government's announcement in the Budget of measures affecting sales tax. Since the legislation is a Budget measure I indicate that the Opposition will not be opposing it. Nevertheless, we want to move to the second reading motion an amendment which is designed to draw attention to some of the serious shortcomings of the administration of the Government in respect of sales tax, and I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of motion, add ``, but the Senate:
(1) notes that this Government has presided over an increasingly inefficient and inequitable indirect tax system that abounds with anomalies and inconsistencies;

(2) calls into question the Government's misguided priorities in increasing sales tax on a number of products, especially on packaging materials, when Australians are already suffering from the highest tax burden in the peace-time history of Australia; and

(3) calls on the Government to undertake a thorough review of the sales tax and indirect tax system in an endeavour to relieve the burden on long-suffering taxpayers and furnish a system that will increase the incentive to save and invest in Australia''.

As I have mentioned, these Bills are part of the overall taxation measures announced in the Budget back in August. They touch on only the indirect or sales tax side of the Budget. But it would be wise in order to set the scene for a discussion about indirect tax along the lines of our amendment to remind ourselves of certain statistics concerning the Budget. We know that total income tax in this Budget compared with the last financial year will increase by some 13.9 per cent, and there will be a 14.4. per cent increase in sales tax collections this year. While that difference in increases is only 0.5 of one per cent-that is, the increase in sales tax collection is only a little greater than the increase in income tax-the fact is that sales tax is still growing faster than is income tax as a whole. That is particularly relevant when compared with last year's outcomes, when we saw income tax increase during the 1988 financial year by 13.6 per cent but sales tax increased by 18.9 per cent.

What we are seeing is an unheralded, unproclaimed switch in emphasis from the raising of taxes through income tax to the raising of taxes by consumption-type taxes under this Government. The trend towards a greater proportion of taxes being raised from indirect sources is still plainly evident in the Government's program and quite obviously that is having some effects on the cost of living, which I will come to in a few minutes when I talk about inflation. First, we must establish that point clearly in the minds of people.

The second point I wish to make is that when we look at the total amount of taxation collected by the Government in terms of a percentage of the gross domestic product (GDP) of the country, we find that the Budget estimates that that increase this year will be 8.3 per cent, bringing the total amount of taxation collected on GDP to 27.3 per cent. In the Budget the Government makes the point that that is about 0.4 per cent, somewhat lower than the percentage of taxation revenue to gross domestic product raised last financial year. We need to adjust that a little because no doubt the Government is claiming credit for reduced taxation. One of the reasons that there has been a decrease in total revenues as distinct from total taxation is that a fall of about $1 billion in the take by the Government from the Reserve Bank of Australia has been indicated for this forthcoming financial year, compared with last year. In other words, the Government will get less from the Reserve Bank this financial year than it did last year. If one adds back that $1 billion profit that will not now be available, one finds that the percentage of gross domestic product being taken by Commonwealth taxation is the same as it was last financial year. Indeed, the Government's argument that somehow it has managed to get the taxation schedules over the slope and on the way down and that we are all headed into a far easier time tax-wise is, of course, just plainly nonsense.

I will now turn to some of the questions about sales tax in particular. As I mentioned, an increase of 14.4 per cent in taxation taken by sales tax this year is mentioned in the Budget. That compares with an increase of 18.9 per cent last year. These figures are running well ahead of inflation and well ahead of inflation plus real growth in the economy. Quite clearly the Government is still moving to increase sales taxes and to rely on a higher percentage of its revenues coming from that source. The Budget Papers indicate that about 6 1/2 per cent of the increase last year came from what might be attributable to the withdrawal of sales tax exemptions for Commonwealth commercial authorities such as Telecom Australia and Australia Post. Certainly that will have accounted for large changes. I do not think we can easily dismiss the impact of that on the economy as being just some kind of statistical aberration. Senator Gareth Evans, who was then Minister for Transport and Communications, and who is now in the chamber, would understand only too well that the imposition of sales taxes on the equipment purchased by Telecom and by other Commonwealth authorities, which I think amounted to something like $400m or $500m last financial year, will have to be recouped by those organisations from the customers of those organisations in the general community. In other words, the taxation that will have to be borne by those bodies through the removal of that exemption has to be translated into higher prices for telephone calls, stamps and other government services provided by them.

Irrespective of any argument about financial accountability and the imposition of proper charges so as to equate the position of Commonwealth authorities with the private sector, the fact remains that the Government is indirectly charging the people of Australia higher taxes by imposing those higher taxes on its own business authorities, which in turn pass those costs on to the community. This is a back door way of imposing taxes on the Australian people and quite clearly has just as inflationary an effect as any other form of taxation which is more directly imposed by the Government on the Australian people.

On the question of sales tax in this last financial year, it is interesting to note some of the increases in the particular rate categories compared with last financial year. For instance, we see that in the most significant and I think the most representative rate class-that is, the 20 per cent rate that applies to most goods and services-the increase in the tax take this financial year will be something like 16.8 per cent compared with the increase last year. I think it is significant to mention that because, as I pointed out earlier, the rate increase this year is somewhat lower than it was last year, but when we look at the area where most items are being taxed, that is, in the 20 per cent rate category, the increase is something of the order of 17 per cent-much higher than the rate of inflation and much higher than the rate of inflation plus real growth in the economy. Therefore, we have a very determined and deliberate action on the part of the Government obviously designed to impose taxes on the Australian people in a way that can be determined or seen only as a consumption tax.

At this point I would like to draw to honourable senators' attention the Opposition's amendment relating to the ramshackle indirect tax system that we have in this country. I point out that again the Government has failed to take the opportunity to reorder the priorities, reorder the system, so as to ensure that we have a proper, more easily understood and more consistent system of indirect taxes, particularly sales tax. That opportunity has been missed again and, quite clearly, if we go on down the track of raising taxes in one category as against others in the way that has been done in this legislation, we are not going to achieve that objective of getting some kind of common sense and uniformity into the multitudinous definitional problems between particular classes of goods. There are quite clearly anomalies and inconsistencies that impose taxes on some things which are only slightly different from others which go free of tax.

Perhaps we should just turn to some of the items which are to be taxed in this legislation and which have not previously been subject to tax. Firstly, I refer to what I call the `tuck shop' tax. That is the imposition of a 10 per cent tax on containers used by retailers for marketing takeaway foods. I shall return to that a little later in relation to the inflation statistics to indicate what effect that is already having in the marketplace. Secondly, a tax will now be applied to thick shakes and ice-creams, also to muesli bars and other health food bars. There also will be an imposition of a 20 per cent tax rate on packaged coffee, chocolate and malt flavoured milk drinks that contain less than 95 per cent milk. It does not sound like a government that has the interests of our children at heart when it imposes taxes on the health food and muesli bars that kids at school buy with their pocket money from the school tuck shop. Obviously it will put more hardship not only on children but also on their families as they have to dig deeper into their pockets to fund their children's lunches at the tuckshops. It is a callous government that would impose such taxes.

This Bill imposes a tax rate of 10 to 20 per cent on wrapping materials for household use. This means that every time we buy something at the supermarket, at takeaway food bars, or whatever, the wrapping material that is used will bear a tax of 10 to 20 per cent. Inevitably that will be reflected in the prices people will have to pay for those products. It means that prices must rise. That is already emerging in the statistics on inflation. The consumer price index (CPI) statistics for the September quarter this year, which came out on 25 October, indicated that food prices rose by 2.8 per cent in that three-month period-a far greater increase than the average for all other commodity categories.

One of the areas where there have been significant increases is the very area we are talking about. Prices of meals out and takeaway foods have increased in all cities. As I have said, the imposition of a tax like this on wrapping or packaging material obviously will be reflected in the prices for these foods. Is it any wonder that increased prices will apply to foods as a result of this direct imposition by the Commonwealth on the Australian people? This tax will tend to fall most heavily on those people who spend most of their income on, if you like, the most staple, basic and fundamental requirements of human life-food being amongst the most important of those requirements. Therefore, those who are on the lowest incomes, such as pensioners, those in receipt of social security benefits and those on other low retirement incomes, will suffer the direct impact of the Government's taxation on packaging. That group will be most affected, because the largest part of those people's incomes goes on food or clothing. It is that category-food-which will bear the greatest impact of this Government's tax measures.

A government would have to be crazy, on the one hand, to say that it is trying to help pensioners by lifting tax incentives and doing things of that kind and, on the other hand, to be taking it out by imposing higher taxes on food. We do well to remind ourselves that back in 1981 the then Labor Opposition, together with the Australian Democrats, I think, opposed taxes on food that might have been applied by the then Fraser Government. Yet this Government is introducing those very measures. I know that Senator Haines cannot wait to dash to her feet to say, `Yes, we still hold that same position, but you in the Opposition are supporting the Government on this Bill'. The reason we are supporting the Bill is that it is a Budget Bill, and we are not going to deny the Government its right to impose taxes as it sees fit. That is a well established principle in this place. It will be only a political stunt by Senator Haines to draw some conclusion that we are supportive in absolute terms of this kind of approach by the Government. She knows full well that we are supporting the Bill because it is part of the Government's Budget.

While we are on the subject of CPI increases, we all know that the quarterly CPI increase announced a week ago indicated a collapse in the Federal Government's Budget strategy. The increase was about 2 per cent-2.6 per cent in Sydney-far greater than the Government estimated in its Budget announced only in August. The increase is almost half of the total CPI increase of 4 1/2 per cent which the Government estimated there would be for the full year. Yet it has occurred in only three months. Obviously, the Government's inflation strategy is in disarray and the inflation is being driven largely by price increases which the Government itself has generated. As I have just pointed out, that has resulted from the imposition of Government sales taxes on the packaging of food and other things.

The second area where the CPI increase has impacted heavily is housing. The increase for the three months just ended in rental and mortgage costs associated with housing and the cost of housing itself was 4 per cent-far ahead of the Government's estimate for the full year. If one were to extrapolate that on a simplistic basis-and I know that that is not entirely logical-one could say that the housing costs of this nation are increasing by 15 to 16 per cent per annum. The Government could not necessarily argue that that is not a fact in this case. We face a disaster in terms of rising living costs for Australians because of the rapid increase in building and housing costs generally. This is largely due to the Government's interest rate policies. Interest rates have increased dramatically in real terms since this Government came to power. We are seeing increased costs imposed on the Australian people as they struggle not only to buy their first homes but also to keep them. This has been difficult, given that incomes have not risen very much over the last five years.

In Victoria from 1985 to 1988 housing costs have increased by 40 to 50 per cent. That must have had, and is having, obviously-from the statistics-a dramatic impact on the cost of living for the average Australian. Quite clearly, under this Government housing is getting beyond even the dreams of Australians. The Government is not helping those who are applying to State housing authorities for rental housing. During this Government's five-year period of office the total number of people seeking assistance from housing commissions in the form of rental housing has increased from 108,000 to 285,000, which demonstrates how effectively this Government is dealing with the problems of ordinary Australians.

The standard of living is falling. As has been pointed out many times by both the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the shadow Treasurer, Mr Peacock, the Australian people would require an increase in their incomes of $56 a week after tax to regain the living standard they enjoyed back in 1983 when this Government came to power. In other words, on average people have lost $56 a week in real terms since this Government came to power 5 1/2 years ago. That is why people are suffering in their pockets. That is why they are finding it more and more difficult to retain their housing. Fifty thousand people are sleeping out of doors these days because they have no housing. That is why 180,000 people are waiting for rental housing through State housing authorities compared with 108,000 people in 1982 when the Fraser Government went out of power. These are the facts. This Government has brought us the lowest living standards since the Depression.

The other area that I would like to touch on relates to retirement incomes as well. Again, I think this demonstrates where the heart of this Government really lies. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that, under the social security legislation, pensioners, retirees who are in receipt of some form of social security benefit, can earn some amount of income without having to pay tax on top of what would already be applicable to their pension. In other words, they can earn an income outside their pension and tax does not apply to that. That amount of money, which would not have attracted tax back in 1982-83-the last year of the Fraser Government-was $999. That meant that nearly $20 a week could be earned without any tax being applied to it. What is the figure today under the Hawke-Keating Government? In this current financial year that amount has fallen to $520. In other words, only $10 a week can be earned-half as much as could be earned in 1983-without attracting taxation. That is seen in dollar terms; that is in nominal money. That does not take into account the change in the value of money since 1982.

In concluding this debate for the Opposition, the point I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate is that those people, those retirees, those pensioners, those beneficiaries, now find that if they get out and earn a little extra money by virtue of part time work or by virtue of careful saving and investment during their working lives, they will suffer taxes at a far greater rate than they did under the former Fraser Government. That is a fact of life and it is a direct result of this Government's policies.

We hear the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) talking about social security policy and retirement income policy in this country and saying that we should be encouraging people to have superannuation for investment purposes to generate other income in their retirement. We also hear them saying, `It is advisable for people to work a little longer or to take part time work after their retirement in order to generate a little extra income and so take the load off the social security system'. But, as I have just pointed out, under this system the incentive is not for people to do those things but is entirely in the opposite direction. Taxation is applied at a higher and higher rate to income that people earn on top of their pensions. Consequently, there is no incentive for people to get off the social security system or to lessen the burden on the taxpayer from their drawings of pensions and other benefits. That, therefore, runs completely in the opposite direction to what this Government claims it is trying to do with its retirement income policy.

Again, this is just more and more evidence of the arrogant, out of touch mode into which this Government has fallen in recent times and which has quite clearly been demonstrated and understood by the people of Australia. Of course, the clear evidence of that is in the recent by-election results in what are and have been called the safe Labor seats of Adelaide, Port Adelaide and Oxley. It looks as though such by-election results will continue while this Government carries on with its misguided policies in handling the affairs of the Australian people. Australian living standards are falling and will continue to fall through this Government's deliberate policies and actions. The sales tax Bills are clear evidence of a continuance of those misguided policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before the Senate today implements changes to sales taxes across the board in a wide range of areas announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on Budget night. I must say that, listening to Senator Messner, I have been touched by his concern for low income families. I found his reference to a tuckshop tax particularly tender, given that none of this would be happening if the current Opposition took the same attitude to this legislation as members of the Opposition did back in 1981. It is all very well for Senator Messner and others to express concern about low income families and what has happened to them under this Government over the last few years, but he needs to remember that the Government can only implement these proposals if the Senate supports them and that means that it has to get a majority of senators in this place on its side. In most of the legislation that has hammered away at low income families and at some middle income families it has not been the Australian Democrats that have supported the legislation but the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand from a Bulletin article of a couple of weeks ago-and one always believes what one reads in magazines of that calibre-that there are some people within the Opposition parties who are now questioning these inane, if not insane, decisions that they made in 1983 to allow the Government to have all its Budget legislation, however appalling they thought it might be. That is something they are obviously regretting but, in the meantime, it has done quite a significant amount of damage to low income families-damage that will be increased by the passage of this legislation.

Those families have already been hard hit. This Government cut Austudy payments for 15-year-olds in the last two years of school. We need to remember that those Austudy payments were going only to very low income families, so those students had their final years of education placed in considerable jeopardy when Liberal and National Party senators here allied themselves with the Government to pass that legislation. Widows of 45 years of age on a class B widow's pension suddenly found themselves standing in queues at Commonwealth Employment Service offices because this Government decided, and the Opposition supported it, that once their youngest child turned 16, they should go off that widow's class B pension and go onto the unemployment benefit-and there are not too many jobs around for women who have been out of the work force raising a family for 20 or more years.

Pensioners had their pre-Christmas consumer price index related increase delayed by this Government and by this Opposition. Increasingly we are seeing low income families hit as this Government succumbs to business pressure to cut its expenditure. It is cutting expenditure in the areas of health, housing, education and social welfare-areas that are all hitting hardest low income families-while allowing corporate welfare to remain alive and well. So we have on the other end of the scale some of the biggest companies in this country paying little or, in the case of the Bond Corporation, no tax on record profits.

I have to say that I remember vividly the debate in 1981 on the Fraser sales tax legislation. Of course, we were in the old Parliament House and the Senate chamber was pretty much packed from beginning to end during the second reading debates. It was an important piece of legislation for the Fraser Government because it was facing a hostile Senate. It was an important piece of legislation for the Labor Opposition because it was doing its best to discredit the Democrats. The legislation that was introduced by the Fraser Government introduced sales tax on a wide range of goods such as furs, gold-plated cutlery, jewellery and artificial flowers for goodness sake and the Labor Opposition in those days wanted the sales tax removed from those things as well as from the things that the Democrats were concerned about, the things that we classified in 1981 as the necessities of life-food, clothing, books, building materials for domestic dwellings, educational materials and newspapers. So inconsistency in oppositions as well as, I guess, in governments is nothing new across the board. But when it comes to sales tax legislation I am disappointed that there is less interest, apparently, in the Parliament in these particular sales tax Bills than there was in the monumental legislation that the Fraser Government introduced in 1981 and faced accepting amendments to. That is what happened in 1981. Amendments were moved to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill or, bearing in mind the constitutional requirements, the Senate requested amendments of the House. That Bill went back and forth from the Senate chamber to the House while we argued whether the Government would accede to the request for amendments. Finally, those items were deleted from the sales tax legislation.

The Government did not crumble in December 1981. Changing that legislation was not the same as what happened in 1975 when a government was denied its right to spend money. It is about time that the Opposition, the public and the media realised that there is a vast difference between the two events; between stopping a government from legally spending money, as happened in 1975 which brought the Government down, and a Senate exercising its legitimate powers as a House of Review and amending what it sees as iniquitous legislation, whether it is brought up as part of a Budget package or not. As a result of the 1983 decision made by the Opposition parties to support all government Budget Bills, whether they are good, bad or indifferent, the Government has now moved to two Budgets a year. We have one in May called the May Economic Statement and we have one brought down in August. So the Government is now guaranteed of getting twice as much legislation through, no matter who will be hurt by it and no matter how anomalous or iniquitous it may be. It is rather ironic that the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris) in his second reading speech had the unmitigated gall to make this statement:
. . . the Bill will correct . . . a number of anomalies and inconsistencies in the various schedules to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act.

What he set about doing, in all but one or two cases, was increasing those charges. The one monumental exception to that-and I do not recall hearing Senator Messner mention it; I apologise if he did and I did not hear it-was that while the Government was happily putting charges on food containers, on various foodstuffs, on other commodities used by ordinary, average Australians and their families, it took off the sales tax on private jets. I find that a pretty amazing way for a government to sort out an anomaly-to increase the cost of living for ordinary Australian families while making sure that those people who could afford a private jet did not have the additional cost of paying sales tax on it. In the meantime, people with some form of disability-say, a thalidomide child-who wish to use a modified computer are required to pay sales tax.

I ask the Minister: Exactly where are the anomalies starting and finishing in that sort of situation? There is no doubt that the sales tax system in this country is in a shambles. Senator Messner was right in that element of his speech today and we will certainly be supporting the second reading attachment that the Opposition has circulated which makes that point loudly and clearly. The sales tax system in this country is full of anomalies. It is a mess. What is worse is that the current legislation further muddies the water by extending the anomalies and I would have thought-and I guess this is a major irony in this place that we are constantly confronted with-runs totally counter to the views expressed on sales taxes by the Australian Labor Party when it is in opposition or when it is appealing to what was its natural constituency, a group of people who must be wondering who now supports them when they are in need.

As I said back in 1981, when the Fraser Government tried to apply a general sales tax on products ranging from gold-plated cutlery to books, clothing, and so on, the then Labor Opposition rose up in righteous indignation. It said that the legislation was iniquitous and unfair, and that it had to be stopped at all costs. It did not want it amended to take out those items that did affect ordinary people; it had to be blocked in toto. `How wimpy the Democrats are', it said. `How typically dithery of them only to want to amend it to take out the necessities of life. You can't have a sales tax on gold-plated cutlery or on furs. We have to defeat the whole package of Bills', the Labor Party claimed in 1981. It was not satisfied simply with removing those items that would damage Australian families, low income ones in particular. Mr Howard, when he was Treasurer, in introducing that sales tax legislation that year said:
. . . the Government-
that is the Fraser Government-
decided earlier this year against a major restructuring of the tax system towards greater reliance on broadly based indirect taxes.
He said that that decision did not rule out later consideration of smaller adjustments within the present system. To this end Mr Howard went on:
. . . the Government-
that is in 1981-
has decided to increase by 2 1/2 per cent each of the existing rates of sales tax, effective in relation to goods passing the taxing point after tonight.
He went on to say:
The legislation will also provide for the correction of a significant number of anomalies and inconsistencies in the sales tax law . . .

In addition, the Government will be bringing in legislation as soon as practicable to tax, at a rate of 2 1/2 per cent, a range of goods that are now exempt-such as clothing, footwear, drapery, soft furnishings, manchester; building materials; books, magazines and newspapers; packaging and wrapping materials-
the very things that Senator Messner today is so angry about-
hand tools; and certain other goods but not including medicines, food or wine.

That is what Mr Howard said in his Budget Speech in August 1981. The Labor Opposition went out of its collective head at the enormous extra cost that was being placed on people. Newspaper headlines echoed the Labor Opposition's criticisms. No journalists, from memory, in 1981, bothered to ask why the Labor Opposition was opposed to a tax on gold-plated cutlery. No journalists pointed out that the previous Whitlam Government had slapped a sales tax on a range of items, including children's soft drinks. Instead they argued, as Labor did, that the Fraser Government's legislation should be opposed in toto.

We were not suggesting that then and we are not suggesting that now. We think that this legislation before us today is open to amendment. My colleague Senator Macklin will, in the committee stage, move an amendment relating to a matter that I raised a moment ago, that is, the serious anomaly that still relates to goods not covered by any other item in the schedule that are used as special aids for people with physical or mental handicaps. That includes such things as computer equipment. We are not saying that somebody should simply write a letter and say, `My child has a disability and I need a special computer'. We have hedged the amendment about with protection as far as the Government is concerned so that there has to be a report from a medical practitioner or somebody else in the medical area who is suitably qualified. I am sure that Senator Macklin, when we get to the committee stage, will put a significant argument both to the Government and to the Opposition to deal properly with this anomaly.

Let us have a look at what has happened since the Australian Labor Party came to office, bearing in mind what it said in 1981-82 about sales tax. Far from ensuring that foodstuffs remain free of sales tax as it claimed they should when it was in opposition, this Government has moved to bring more and more items into the sales tax schedules. This is except, of course, as I said, for private jets which have now become sales tax exempt on the grounds, according to the Government, that it is too difficult to administer. It is apparently not too difficult to administer the sales tax on containers for takeaway food, for ice-creams or for flavoured soya milk, but it is too difficult to administer a sales tax on private jets. The Government has seen fit to make certain foodstuffs now liable to sales tax.

These foodstuffs all incur the rate of 10 per cent sales tax: confectionery; ice-cream; biscuits; savoury snacks and their ingredients; packaged, flavoured milk drinks provided that they consist of not less than 95 per cent milk-any less than that and they get hit with a higher tax-packaged fruit juice products; fermented alcoholic beverages, including wines and ciders but not beverages that contain more than 1.15 per cent alcohol; and beers and spirits about which I will say more later because this has to be the biggest con trick on the CPI we have seen for a while; and containers for the abovementioned goods.

Not only will most of these increase housekeeping costs, as Senator Messner said, but for low income families in particular they will force parents to cut back on treats for their children. It will not bother me particularly that confectionery, ice-cream, biscuits and savour snacks and their ingredients have gone up by 10 per cent. Most of the time I do not eat those products. My children are both in the work force and can more than adequately afford to provide their own. But any family living on some sort of pension or benefit, any family living on considerably less than average weekly earnings or indeed any family living on average weekly earnings with several children will find itself saying more and more to those children, `No, I am sorry we can't afford it'. Beer, however, along with private planes, has been the exception in all of this.

I do not want to get into the gender debate. But it is a fact that when it comes to things like purchasing confectionery, ice-cream, biscuits and what have you, it is the adult female of the household whose housekeeping has to stretch to cover that increase. Very few women, as far as I know, however, own private planes. So they will not benefit from the sales tax cut. I would love to know a woman who did. Senator Reynolds is nodding her head in agreement. I do not know if there is one but I doubt it very much. Beer is not something that most women purchase at 5.30 or 6.00 at night on their way home from work. What do we see happening? The Government has decided to remove the sales tax exemption for beer so that all beer will be subject to a tax at the 20 per cent rate irrespective of the volume of alcohol or country of manufacture.

However, excises have been reduced. As a consequence the overall price of beer has dropped. Coincidentally, this has affected the CPI which should now drop by around 0.03 per cent. It is an amazing coincidence that this should occur. I might also point out that in some areas this drop in the price of beer has been slow coming in any event as the manufacturers, the publicans, or somebody else has seen the heaven sent opportunity to make a windfall profit in all of this by upping the sales tax but not reducing the excise and not passing the cuts on to the consumer. Where it has happened I guess the cynics in here, of whom I occasionally count myself as one, would say that the action was taken by a government keen to woo the working man's vote again and keen to con the journalists who were interested in such things into believing that the CPI will drop as a result of other actions that the Government has taken to straighten out the Australian economy. We now have hit those confectionery items that I mentioned: muesli bars; health foods; ice-cream mixes; thick shake mixes; packaged flavoured milk and soya milk.

Plain milk, I would point out, is at present exempt from sales tax although flavoured milk is not. Under the proposed changes beverages consisting wholly or principally of soya milk will be exempt. However, presumably in order not to create an anomaly in the case of packaged flavoured milk the rate of 10 per cent applies. This will also now apply to flavoured beverages consisting principally of soya milk. I do not know whether the Government is aware of the fact that there are an increasing number of children in this community who cannot physically tolerate milk or milk products. Their parents turn to soya milk products as an alternative. Soya milk is not to everyone's taste. It is certainly not to a great many children's taste. Adding a little flavouring sometimes helps the medicine go down. What does this Government do? It taxes it. Presumably it does this on the grounds that if one has a sick child it is one's fault in much the same way as the Government is saying, `Don't blame us for children in poverty. Blame the parents who can't run their expenditure properly'. So the Government allows soya milk to be tax free but the minute it is sold with any flavouring in it it is taxed.

Let me come back to this question of sales taxes on private aircraft because it has, I think-the Minister may care to correct me on this-another interesting anomaly. We are removing this sales tax because, according to the explanatory memorandum, there are in fact very few taxable sales of aircraft and the cost of administering the current law is high. We also find hidden in the sales tax increases things such as bathroom fittings. I would like the Minister to tell me something, just as a matter of curiosity-because of the position the Opposition is taking we cannot do much about it. If a family purchases bathroom fittings for their home, are those fittings liable to sales tax? If, however, the fittings are put in John Elliott's plane or somebody else's private jet so that they have a sumptuous bathroom to go to after drinking all that beer, are the fittings sales tax exempt? If they are, they ought not to be.

Despite what the Minister said in his second reading speech, this legislation goes nowhere at all in correcting anomalies. It certainly does not improve the standard of living of low and middle income earners. It goes no way at all to fulfilling a Labor government's commitment to people who, if they are not currently living in poverty, soon will be. It is a further example of the way in which, when it suits governments, they can help their business mates and do it at the expense of their traditional supporters. I hope the Opposition will think again about the only amendment we will be moving during the committee stage. It is clearly pointless for us to try to amend the legislation so that things like flavoured soy milk continue to be exempt, because I presume we are not going to get any support for that. However, there is a very real problem for people with disabilities who need access to certain equipment, including computers, which when suitably adapted for them assist in improving their living standards and increasing their learning capacity. I would ask the Opposition at least to consider that.

As has been pointed out in the second reading attachment to this piece of legislation, the sales tax field is full of anomalies. We agree. We will be supporting that attachment. In return I ask the Opposition to support the one amendment we will be moving, which will make life a lot easier for kids with disabilities and for the families of children with disabilities, and which will remove a most unpleasant anomaly in the current sales tax legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the changes to sales tax which were brought about by the recent Budget. Before I go into that I wish to comment on some of the remarks of Senator Haines. The Australian Democrats show the greatest hypocrisy in this place. We are consistent in that we come in here and talk about reduced government spending and reduced taxes. We complain bitterly about the level of taxation and the complexity of the taxation system. There is a consistency about our complaints. The Australian Democrats come in here and side with the Government or seek to initiate programs which involve the destruction of the wealth-creating industries in this country and at the same time demand increases in government expenditure. The two things are absolutely irreconcilable.
—Name one.

—Everyone in the country is aware of what has happened to the Democrats in recent years, particularly since the resignation of Senator Chipp. They have become the left wing of the Australian Labor Party. What we have in this legislation is a classic example of taxation by stealth. The Government talks about rationalisation of the sales tax law. What they mean by that, of course, is to pick up things they forgot the last time they amended the sales tax law. As a result, a whole range of consumer goods at the youth end of the market will now be slugged with sales tax. This could be called the `kick the kids' section of the 1988-89 Budget. The Treasurer (Mr Keating), not content with plundering individual taxpayers and businesses, is now taxing children. These pocket-money pinching measures include a tax at 20 per cent, which was not there before, on all pre-packaged coffee, chocolate and malt flavoured milk drinks with less than 95 per cent milk; a tax at 10 per cent on containers used in marketing biscuits, snack foods, ice-cream and take away food and drinks; a tax at 10 per cent on thick shake mixes and ice-cream mixes; a tax at 10 per cent on muesli bars and similar health food bars. It could be said that the Treasurer, Captain Snatch, strikes again. The alterations brought about by these Bills include the removal of beer excise and the reduction in sales tax on some goods such as cosmetics.

SPEECH.PARA: To pretend that these changes will significantly reform sales tax is plainly ridiculous. The legislation is just a cynical attempt to manipulate the inflation rate by tampering with beer prices in order to restore credibility to the Treasurer's forecast in the Budget that the inflation rate will be down to 4.5 per cent by June next year. As the latest consumer price index (CPI) figures show, the Treasurer's forecast of around 7.3 per cent annualised is like the beer-all froth and bubble. Meanwhile, these changes will create only more problems for Australia's 80,000 small businessmen, who must try to operate within the Government's tangled sales tax web, and what a tangled web it is.

Complaints against the sales tax system as we know it include a whole range of businesses being inadequately informed of Australian Taxation Office rulings-rulings which are so complex and obscure that business people must regularly seek legal and professional advice to clarify them. Inconsistencies vary from State to State. This is not new; it goes back years. I am aware of that. As an example, Senator Brownhill and I have been trying for months to clarify whether simple things like chainsaws purchased by farmers and agriculturalists are exempt from sales tax. After many letters and phone calls over a period of months, the position is still not very clear. I think it is worth recounting briefly the details of this case because it nicely illustrates what an absolute dog's breakfast the sales tax system is, not to mention the bureaucratic trivia that people trying to run businesses in this country have to contend with.

As I said at the beginning of this debate, the problem is not just the level of taxation in this country, which is enormously high-too high-and penalises everyone from the lower socioeconomic group right through; it is also the complexity of the tax system. The income tax system is complex enough but the sales tax system is incredibly complex. The saga began when a Queensland business which sells chainsaws predominantly to rural people received a ruling from the Taxation Office branch in Brisbane that chainsaws could be purchased exempt from sales tax only if they were used in manufacturing fence posts for sale. Following representations on the issue this ruling was withdrawn within about a month and a new ruling made that farmers and other primary producers could buy chainsaws exempt from sales tax if they were used primarily and principally for manufacturing fence posts or stockyards, either for their own use or for sale.

The problem is how one defines `primarily and principally'. What does it mean? Several letters to the Australian Taxation Office later it was established that `primarily and principally' refers to 50 per cent or more of the use of the saw. That clarified the position in Queensland to some extent.

However, south of the border, in New South Wales, Senator Brownhill was told a quite different story when he made inquiries about sales tax exemptions for these items which are an essential part of the majority of rural properties. He received all the information I did, but the New South Wales sales tax branch also added that in its opinion, while the sales tax ruling permits exemptions to be claimed on chainsaws, it thought it unlikely that farmers would actually be able to do so since few farmers would meet the test of using their saws primarily and principally for making wooden fence posts or building stockyards. This advice is not being given by the Queensland sales tax office, to the advantage of the graziers in Queensland. Subsequently farmers claim and receive the exemption, while their southern counterparts over the border are not permitted to do so. Just in case any problems arise with the Taxation Office, chainsaw retailers in Queensland have now sought legal opinion confirming that the rulings from the Queensland branch imply that they can offer the sales tax exemptions to primary producers. I am told that it is just pot luck when it comes to receiving sales tax exemptions. It depends on whether one is dealing with a sympathetic sales tax officer.

Questions were also raised about whether a farmer could claim a tax exemption on a chainsaw if he could establish that the chainsaw was used primarily and principally as an aid to manufacture-for example, pruning fruit trees or cutting mulga to feed stock in drought stricken areas, which is not uncommon, as Senator Burns, who is now in the chair, will be aware from his experience in that State. This opened a real can of worms. Sales tax exemptions can be claimed if a hand tool is used as an aid to manufacture, but only if it fits within the Taxation Office's ruling on the definition of the word `manufacture'. Manufacture in this case means severing from the land, harvesting or breeding. A farmer can claim sales tax exemption for a tool that he uses to pick fruit from trees, but cannot claim for a chainsaw which he uses to prune those trees. He could claim sales tax exemption for a tool which harvests his crops, but not for a tool which sows the seeds of those crops; but primary producers can claim exemption for chainsaws when they are used to clear noxious weeds and scrub.

Without going into any more detail, I believe that the worst aspect is that this is inconsistent, anomalous and unfair. If a system that is supposed to be Australia-wide contains such anomalies, I believe that it is drastically wrong. So much for this Government which, four years ago, said that it would set up a summit to look at the tax system and that one of its major aims would be to simplify the system. The Government has not got anywhere near that situation and in fact has gone in the opposite direction.

It is patently obvious-and I do not have to remind the people of Australia of this fact-that we now have the highest taxing government this country has ever seen outside wartime conditions. To give some examples, in 1983-84 the consumer price index increased by 3.9 per cent. The reason that it was so low flowed from the Fraser Government's wage freeze in the previous year. If we believe the CPI figure in the Treasurer's Budget Speech, as I will for the purpose of this exercise, the total CPI increase for the period 1983-84 to 1988-89 was about 50 per cent. In Japan in the same period the CPI was around 6.5 per cent. However, be that as it may, the sales tax increase over the same period, with an increase in CPI of 50 per cent, has been 147 per cent. I know people will argue that some growth is involved, and that is true, but even when one adds in the growth factor the figure is still incredibly bad. We have an absolute wrong sense of priorities.

There are two areas where we are reasonably successful. One is the mining industry and the other is in agriculture. When we compare the manufacturing industry with industries in the rest of the world, particularly our South East Asian neighbours and the more developed countries, we must conclude that we are a Third World country. One of the major reasons is that the level of taxation imposed by this Government has made it impossible for people to be able to invest in such things as high-tech research and development. Industry is criticised for this, but nobody asks why. There are many answers, but a major answer is that industries do not have the generative income to do these things because the Government rips off their income. In fact, one of the few honest people on the other side, Senator Cook, is renowned for his statement `We are a high taxing government, because we have to be to implement our reforms'. I think the people of Australia are suddenly discovering that that is the case.

Senator Macklin interjected and asked for one example where the Democrats go out of their way to affect the wealth-producing industries of this country. However, no matter what subject comes up in the mining industry, with few execptions the Democrats find a reason as to why it should not happen. We have heard all the language, whether from Senator Sanders or some of his predecessors; whenever a proposal arises they kick it to death. Yet without that industry our standards of living in this country would be much lower than they are today-and, for God's sake, they are low enough. In conclusion I wish to add my support to the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Messner in relation to this amending Bill in the following terms:
At end of motion, add `, but the Senate:
(1) notes that this Government has presided over an increasingly inefficient and inequitable indirect tax system that abounds with anomalies and inconsistencies;
I am pleased to hear that, on this rare occasion, Senator Haines and her Democrat colleagues will be supporting the Opposition. The amendment continues:

(2) calls into question the Government's misguided priorities in increasing sales tax on a number of products, especially on packaging materials, when Australians are already suffering from the highest tax burden in the peace-time history of Australia; and

(3) calls on the Government to undertake a thorough review of the sales tax and indirect tax system in an endeavour to relieve the burden on long-suffering taxpayers and furnish a system that will increase the incentive to save and invest in Australia.

This Government has a preoccupation with taxing individuals and companies. I am not referring to people who evade or avoid tax, as I believe they should pay their taxes. But I am saying that, while the level of tax imposed in this country continues to grow, there is no way in the world that this country will get itself off the floor, increase the level of its manufacturing sector and thus provide jobs and the wealth needed to be able to pay for government programs.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time in the Senate yesterday Senator Sanders asked be about removal procedures of the Bogong moths which have confused this building with the Brindabella Mountains. Honourable senators will have noticed that the situation worsened considerably overnight. The only places inside the building which have been severely affected are the President's walkway and office on this side of the building and similar areas in the Speaker's suite. The cleaning staff, faced with thousands of moths in the walkway early this morning, undertook limited spraying with a commonly available household spray. This operation was carried out by properly equipped and protected cleaning personnel. I have been informed that this technique of dealing with the moths inside the building was necessary for the safe operation of vital functions in the building-especially the air-conditioning.

INTERJECT.PARA: The advice received by the Joint House Department from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is that there is nothing which can be done about the moths on the outside of the building. TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training seen reports claiming that the Government has made `ridiculous grants' to the trade union movement for educational and humanitarian aid programs? Do these claims have any basis in fact, and in particular are the allegations concerning direct Government grants to the Australian Teachers Federation (ATF) justified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume the claims to which Senator Zakharov has referred are those reported in the May-July issue of the Institute of Public Affairs Review, in an article written by Senator Short. He claimed in his article that the Teachers Federation had received from the Government $8,000 for training in the community program for female teachers in Australia; $4,700 for a teacher-trade union seminar; $7,000 for an orientation program for the All India Secretary Teachers Association-that is Secretary, sic; $10,000 to the Pacific Teachers Trade Union Trainers; $5,000 for continuing education for Anglican teachers on the West Bank; $12,000 for an English as a second language training program in Tanzania; and $7,500 for a health worker training program in Phnom Penh.

ANSWER.PARA: The first point I make is that the last of those grants, the one relating to Cambodia, was not even made to the ATF. As I think I have said before in this chamber, I have had recent discussions with him and with this Government's Aboriginal Affairs Minister, the Hon. Gerry Hand. —I ask the Minister for Local Government a supplementary question. Firstly, can she do even better than that and ask her senior private secretary, Dr Hazel Moir, before the end of Question Time whether that person has received such a letter? Secondly, can she advise the Senate just what action has been taken by her in relation to the Warumungu Town Council?
—I imagine that my office is already aware of this inquiry and I will get a response for the honourable senator as quickly as possible.
—I ask the Minister for Local Government: What is the International Union of Local Authorities and what is Australia's relationship with this organisation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Union of Local Authorities (IULA) is holding its twenty-ninth congress in Australia next year. I am sure that the city of Perth is very pleased that it has been chosen as the site for this congress. Given the debate that has gone on in Australia over the past six months, particularly about the role and responsibilities of local government, I think it is most appropriate that the congress is being held in Australia next year. The Office of Local Government is a member of the International Union of Local Authorities. This worldwide representative organisation of local government was founded in 1913 and is based in The Hague. Perhaps the longevity of the organisation indicates quite clearly just how long local government has played a very important role in communities throughout the world, and indeed here in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: During the recent referendum debate many people were suggesting that local government, with its responsibilities, was somehow a new, challenging and radical proposition. I think that the existence of this organisation indicates just how long local government has been important and how it is recognised in international forums. IULA's objectives are to strengthen the status and capacity of local government, which I am sure Opposition senators would agree with; to raise the standard of local administration; to encourage citizens to participate in community affairs; and to promote cooperation and consultation among councils and, I hope, in intergovernmental relations.

IULA has compiled a worldwide declaration of local self-government, which is currently under review by the United Nations. This issue was raised at the local government Ministers conference in Brisbane in June this year and I am currently seeking the advice of Ministers in all States before determining what the Australian Government's response will be. As I said earlier, the twenty-ninth congress to be held in Perth next year will be an ideal opportunity for Australia to demonstrate proudly the work it does in local government and, indeed, to learn of local government initiatives in other parts of the world.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PAPUA NEW GUINEA-INDONESIAN BORDER: AUSTRALIAN ARMY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, concerns media reports that the Australian Government is considering stationing an Australian Army unit some 20 kilometres from the Papua New Guinea- Indonesian border. While acknowledging the reality that border skirmishes involving the Indonesians will continue for some time, I ask whether the Australian Government is considering a move that could increase the likelihood of the Australian military becoming entangled in future Indonesian Papua New Guinea conflict? Secondly, in his recent visit to Indonesia did the Minister raise with the Indonesian authorities the prospect of Australia moving an Army engineering unit to within 20 kilometres of the Papua New Guinea-Indonesian border and, if so, what was their response? Did he also raise the possibility of a joint Australian-Indonesian effort to improve infrastructure and therefore communications on the border between the two countries? If this question of a joint team was raised, was the Indonesian response positive?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposal to station a unit of Australian engineers to assist in road construction and similar civil projects has been discussed now for some two years. It is not a recent proposal; it is not in any sense a response to recent events on the border or anywhere else in Papua New Guinea, but is just an example of an extended area of possible defence cooperation. There has been such a team of engineers in Papua New Guinea stationed in Mendi and before that in Popondetta for some 25 years. The unit involves some 25 professional engineers and support staff and the concept was to do something the same elsewhere in the country.

ANSWER.PARA: The argument for locating that particular unit in the west Sepik area around Vanimo is fairly compelling in terms of the quality of the road system there and the inadequacy of that road system for the purposes of effective administration of the border area from the Papua New Guinea side. Locating the unit there is an attractive option and is acknowledged as such by the Papua New Guinea Government, as well as by the Australian defence side, but no final decision has yet been made to do so. That decision will certainly depend on the final response we receive from the Papua New Guinea Government. That response will, in turn, undoubtedly take into account the questions of possible sensitivities about the location of the unit in a particular area-not only foreign government sensitivities but also some of the local political sensitivities of those who might be missing out on road construction as a result of its being located close to the border. All those issues remain to be finally talked through and resolved, although they were aired in a very constructive way in the two-day meeting that I have just concluded in Wewak with my colleague the Minister for Defence, Mr Kim Beazley, and the counterpart Papua New Guinea Ministers.

On the question of a likely Indonesian reaction, I did not specifically raise that issue in the course of my extensive discussions with the Indonesian Government because it simply had not come to the point of a decision being made or even imminent on the PNG side as to where it wanted the unit located. However, on the basis of the general scope and flavour of those discussions that we did have about the border issue, I would be very surprised indeed if the Indonesians responded to the location of such a unit in, say, the Vanimo area in anything other than a positive way.

The Indonesian Government is concerned to improve-as we all are-the quality of communications, both physical and telephonic, in that region in order that there can be a greater focus of resources on both sides of the border on administering that volatile and sensitive area and doing so in an effective way. Clearly, the construction of an effective road system on the PNG side would contribute to that more effective administration. These are no doubt issues that Mr Somare will canvass with his Indonesian counterparts in the course of the visit he proposes to make to Indonesia in the next few days. There has been no discussion of which I am aware-certainly none in which I participated-about any joint Australian- Indonesian exercise being directed towards infrastructure, communications or anything else. I am aware only of the matters to which I have already referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer noticed a newspaper article in which Senator Sheil has allegedly `blasted the Commonwealth Government for selling census information to private enterprise'? Is one of the reasons for census collections to allow government and non-government agencies to make future plans based on sound statistical data?
