Is this senator unnecessarily causing concern to citizens, instead of outlining to them how the information they provide at census time helps in Australia's economic and social development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a copy of the article. Indeed, I have it here. The answers to the four questions, in short, are yes, yes, no and yes; but I will say a little more than that. The kindest thing I can think of to say about this little report attributable to Senator Sheil is that it is not nearly as silly as the letters he was writing to Senator Ray a while ago, complaining that his electoral staff were not paid when they had been working in the office for 14 months but Senator Sheil had not bothered to tell Senator Ray, the Department or anybody else that they were so working.

ANSWER.PARA: The plain fact is that the Government spends about $127m a year at present on running the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). Senator Sheil seems to believe that no information pursuant to the statistics that are collected should be released to the public. I stress that the Act explicitly prohibits the ABS making available to the public information that identifies any individual. Indeed, it would be a breach of the Act to make such information available to other branches of government, as I recall it. So, on a non-identifiable basis it would make little sense if the large amount of money spent on the ABS was to provide information to government only and not to provide to the private sector information which is useful to it and which assists in the functioning of the economy; for example, such basic information as the current size of the work force and likely changes in the size of the work force.

After Senator Sheil gets through that, he drifts into spurious arguments about privacy-a technique that he picked up, I presume, from reading too many League of Rights publications. But I also notice that that paranoia, as exhibited in the League of Rights publications, is still being parroted, unfortunately, by a number of members of the Opposition, although I note for the record that, with the exception of Senator Sheil, the Queensland National Party seems to have finally realised that the League of Rights was a bit of a viper that it was nurturing-that it was a willing source of assistance in the past but has now become an electoral threat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order on the point of relevance. The Minister, as usual, has wandered widely. I have been very patient. I ask you to call him to order and to ask him to conclude his answer.
—Many of the Minister's comments were not relevant to the question that he was asked. I ask him to be more relevant.

—I had finished. Senator Sheil seems to have become really hooked on this sort of sensational, paranoid stuff. Perhaps after 14 years in the Senate and not having been noticed, except for about six hours in 1981, I think it was, he thinks he has to try to justify his existence. But he is not doing anything for himself and he is certainly not doing anything for the country.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the media release of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs of 31 October 1988, in which he announced that the Commonwealth Auditor-General will undertake an audit of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). Can the Minister assure the Senate that the absolute integrity of all files of the Aboriginal Development Commission or the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, in both central and regional offices which are relevant to the grave issues raised in last week's Estimates Committee E will be guaranteed and that such files will in no way be interfered with prior to their being made available for inspection by the Auditor-General?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I certainly can do is give a guarantee of the absolute integrity of the Auditor-General.
—That was not the question.

—I know that. I know that the honourable senator is not asking that. The point is that I am quite sure that the Auditor-General's particular skills and experience will be brought to bear in a way which would quickly reveal any such action which Senator Stone seems to suppose might be taken. I certainly do not accept the premise of the question, which seems to be that officers within either the Department of Aboriginal Affairs or the Aboriginal Development Commission would be so lacking in the proprieties and integrity which are so important, particularly where there is expenditure of moneys on the scale that is involved, that they would undertake a culling or an alteration of the records and files in a way which would mislead the Auditor-General in his investigations. I am convinced that the co-operation which the Auditor-General will be seeking will be forthcoming from the officers of both organisations and will enable him to examine the books of both organisations in a way which will be satisfactory.

ANSWER.PARA: This relates in a certain way to the question that was asked of me yesterday about why the Department of Aboriginal Affairs was not subject to this special audit. Senator Stone would know that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is subject to constant audit by the Auditor-General--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the question.

—No; but what I am saying is that already there is a process in place which would ensure, in the case of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, that the Auditor-General was well aware of its methods, its bookkeeping and its mode of operation. I am sure, as I say, that the sort of cooperation that has been a marked feature of the relations between the Auditor-General and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs will be seen to be the case again as he undertakes this investigation.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Whilst I thank the Minister for his answer, I note that he did not, himself, offer the guarantee that I requested. I understand that the Minister himself, of course, cannot take personal custody of those files. But I ask the Minister: Will he take a personal interest in the future of the files in question?
—I am the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I am quite sure that he is well able to discharge his portfolio responsibilities with integrity.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training seen the article in the Age on 12 October entitled, `Girls who want to be chippies', which reports that, whilst many young women have successfully completed non-traditional trades training and apprenticeships, employers are overlooking skilled tradeswomen, even while industry cries out for skilled workers? Will the Government say what it is doing to encourage employers to hire the increasing number of skilled tradeswomen?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must confess that I have not seen the article, but I have here a report which supplies some information relevant to it. The Government is pursuing a number of measures to encourage the participation of women in non-traditional trades. To that end, a working group of Commonwealth and State officials, known as the Commonwealth-State Training Advisory Committee on Women in Apprenticeships, was set up in 1986 to consider measures which might lead to the increasing participation of women in that area. One of the initiatives currently being pursued provides for joint Commonwealth-State funding for `tradeswomen on the move', projects designed to encourage young women to consider a non-traditional trade as a viable career option through the provision of role models.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth is also providing $700,000 in this financial year to State and Territory governments for designated preparatory course places for women. The Commonwealth and Territory governments introduced the Australian traineeship system in 1985 as a means of improving structured training opportunities for all young people.

In conclusion, this is an area, like employment areas or qualification and training areas in general, in which the direct role of the Commonwealth Government is necessarily somewhat limited because State legislation usually controls such matters. But it is quite clear that the Commonwealth has exercised quite properly a coordinating and leadership role and has encouraged the States, hopefully, to all take some action which will be effective in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade detail for the Senate the advances made in Australian-Indonesian relationships by the claims of a Mr Lamb that hundreds of helpless children have been murdered in East Timor-claims about which Mr Lamb has repeatedly said that he has not the slightest element of proof?

—I think I have already said sufficient on that subject while I was away. It was widely reported and there is no need for me to repeat it now. Obviously, I remain willing, as does any Labor Foreign Minister, to take up questions of human rights abuse if we believe there is some kind of sound prima facie case, or some reasonably substantial evidentiary base, on which such a proposition could be put forward. Up until now I have received no such sound prima facie material or substantial evidentiary base, so at this stage it would be quite premature for the matter to be pursued in the form of representations by me of the kind that Mr Lamb was apparently wanting me to make. Nonetheless, if any such evidence comes forward, I would be only too happy to raise the matter. In fact, I foreshadowed in my discussions with the Indonesian Foreign Minister that, just as we systematically and consistently raise human rights issues with other friendly and less friendly governments all round the world, so too we would continue to do so in the future; and we discussed ways and means and channels through which such representations and requests for information could be made. Of course, that is a practice that I intend to follow in the future.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The question the Foreign Minister was asked was: What advances were made in Australian-Indonesian relationships by that statement? It was not a question about the pursuit of human rights issues by members of the Australian Labor Party. If the Minister can find time to talk to the press, he can certainly find time to meet his responsibilities and answer to the Parliament, because the function of the Executive Government is to be accountable for its actions.
—Order! Senator MacGibbon, ask your question.
—What is the position? How were Australia's relationships advanced by those unsubstantiated allegations that I view as being irresponsible?
—I think Senator MacGibbon can make his own judgment on that matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PAPUA NEW GUINEA: MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING ON QUARANTINE MATTERS

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that yesterday the Minister for Resources concluded a memorandum of understanding with the Government of Papua New Guinea covering consultation on quarantine matters. Could the Minister inform the Senate of the benefits that will flow from the memorandum and also from the more general discussions that he had with Papua New Guinea Ministers on matters pertaining to his portfolio?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —According to the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, the gross value of rural production in Australia this financial year will be $21.6 billion. It is because we have a clean herd and a very healthy and clean crop that we are able to realise that sort of income. One of the key aspects of guaranteeing that we can earn that type of income is for the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to conclude memorandums of agreement, such as the one we signed in Wewak yesterday when I was with a delegation of Australian Ministers, led by Senator Gareth Evans, at a ministerial forum taking place between Papua New Guinea Ministers, led by Michael Somare, and Australian Ministers as a consequence of a joint declaration of principles between our two countries.

ANSWER.PARA: Papua New Guinea, like Australia, is free from rabies, foot and mouth disease, Newcastle disease and pork measles in terms of cattle, chicken and pig diseases. From a grains point of view it is also free of khapra beetle, the moko disease which affects bananas, blister blight which affects tea, and fruit fly. It is in the interests of both countries that we jointly cooperate, particularly in the Torres Strait, to make sure for both our sakes that we remain free of those diseases; and indeed, because across the border in Irian Jaya Newcastle disease and examples of pork measles have been found in their virulent form.

The memorandum of agreement that we have concluded with Papua New Guinea guarantees that we will have a regional quarantine strategy to protect ourselves in the cases of all of those diseases; that we will run joint surveys to identify problems, particularly in Torres Strait; that we will harmonise our quarantine procedures so that the indigenous peoples living in Torres Strait, on both sides of the border, can be under a simplified and understandable regime and know what that regime is, and be able to go about their normal subsistence fishing and continue their lifestyles without undue delay; and that we will exchange information on pests and diseases as they occur. From a quarantine point of view it is quite an important development for Australia and one that I would hope to emulate with Indonesia when we seek later to conclude a similar memorandum of understanding with that country from a quarantine point of view so that our forward defences on quarantine are intact.

Senator Giles asked me what other matters of a resources nature were dealt with at the forum. I think a number of important issues were canvassed between me and the the Papua New Guinea Ministers. Just to name a few, we discussed under what circumstances the vessel Rig Seismic, our offshore seismic surveying vessel, might be able to be used in Papua New Guinea waters, particularly in areas where there is thought to be high prospectivity for oil and gas. We talked about the possibility of sharing greater information between our two countries-both of us are major resource countries-on what the market holds for resources, and that is an important aspect for Papua New Guinea from a gold as well as a copper point of view. We talked about sharing the environmental package that the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory have in place for offshore drilling so that that environmental package could be used by Papua New Guinea, if it so chooses, in any offshore work done in its waters on the Continental Shelf. I was able to say that, from discussions with a number of major Australian companies, there is a great deal of interest in resource exploration in Papua New Guinea, and indeed, in the case of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and the recent riots that occurred at Ok Tedi, that company, as the company that has now taken over the operation of the Ok Tedi goldmine, has recognised some of the underlying problems that gave rise to those riots. BHP, as a good corporate citizen in Papua New Guinea, is keen to address those problems to remove that type of friction that might occur in a remote mining settlement. I thought it was a very useful and productive exchange, and it must strengthen the cooperation between our two countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications explain to the Australian public why on only two occasions out of the last 120 years the formation of roads and bridges relative to the gross domestic product has been lower than it is at present? I remind the Minister that those two occasions were during the First World War and the Second World War. Further, how does the Government explain to the people of Australia the calculations of the Australian Local Government Association, which has compared current construction and maintenance spending on roads against vehicle density in the mid-1980s, clearly showing that road spending is now half of the mid-1960 levels, and all this at a time when local governments are being forced to spend almost $300m more on roads than the Commonwealth Government?

—If it is the case that road funding is describable in the way that Senator Calvert puts it, the explanation that I would offer is that the funding is proportionately lower now because we have spent so much money, and we have spent it so effectively and so much better than our predecessors did who wound down so dramatically the proportion of funding that was being devoted to national roads and highways. It is simply not necessary to spend the same amount of money as it was in our earlier years of government. No doubt, my colleague Mr Robert Brown is full bottle on this matter as always. If he wishes to add anything to that answer I will convey it to the honourable senator.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. While the Minister is passing those matters on to his opposite number in the other House could he ask him how the Government can suggest that local government maintain and develop its vital local road network with the abysmal one cent that it gets out of the 21.53c that Keating and his cronies take at the bowser?
—Order! That is another question.

—I will suggest that the Minister answer the question by making the very obvious point that the local government component of road funding has in fact been maintained in real terms in the current Budget.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH AFRICA: FREEDOM OF THE PRESS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has his attention been drawn to broadcasts made today by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation which claim that the Weekly Mail, South Africa's last important anti-apartheid media bastion, has been forced out of operation and suspended for one month by the Government, apparently for threatening the security of that nation? Has the Australian Government taken any action in this matter through either diplomatic discussion or government to government talks in the light of this obvious deterioration in South Africa's world standing, especially in regard to freedom of the press?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that the South African Government has announced the suspension for a month of a Johannesburg English language newspaper, the Weekly Mail. The suspension was made under the draconian censorship laws which exist in that country and which are aimed squarely at gagging the media. They are laws which have been used to stifle other newspapers critical of the Government, including the Catholic New Nation, whose editor is currently being held in detention without trial. These developments offer ample rebuttal to those apologists for South Africa who are so often reminded these days to claim that the situation in that country is improving, that somehow there is some greater evidence of sensitivity to the abomination of apartheid than was the case previously. Manifestly that is not so and, here again, is living proof and evidence of that.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government deplores the harassment of the Weekly Mail. It is a respected newspaper which is well known for its depth of coverage of events in South Africa, including human rights issues, for its balance and for its integrity. The gagging of press freedom in South Africa will not make that country's political problems go away. What is needed is not less information but more open debate, and genuine freedom of expression, so that the ongoing conflict in that country can be resolved by peaceful political means.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. In light of repeated assertions by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that he knew nothing of the proposed dismissal of Mr Mick O'Brien by the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) before it occurred, and in light of the presence in Adelaide at the time of the dismissal of the departmental officer who took Mr O'Brien's place, is it a fact that Mr Cedric Wyatt, the DAA regional director for Western Australia, required authority to travel from Perth to Adelaide at public expense? Was Acting Commissioner Perkins, also Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, involved in any way with the facilitation or authorisation of that travel? Given that there was involvement of some of his most senior officers in parts of this unsavoury affair, does the Minister continue to assert that he had no prior knowledge or involvement in the events that led to the replacement of the General Manager of the ADC by a senior officer of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs?

—I have relayed an answer to this chamber previously to the effect that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs was unaware of the matters which were to be the subject of such controversies as transpired at the meeting of the Aboriginal Development Commission held in Adelaide. I have no reason to suppose that that response is to be changed. I am trying to recall the actual Estimates Committee hearing when Mr Cedric Wyatt's travel to Adelaide was raised. I think his response was to the effect that while he had the ability to travel outside the jurisdiction of Western Australia, which was his responsibility he, nevertheless, thought it necessary to give some sort of indication that he was about to do so. I do not think he actually had to apply for permission to travel outside of Western Australia.
—Yes, he did. He did not have the jurisdiction.

—I would like to have a look at the Estimates Committee transcript as to the relationship between Mr Wyatt's travelling from Western Australia to Adelaide-I think it was on the second day of the meeting-and the request of the Aboriginal Development Commission which had contacted him, I guess through an officer of the Commission, asking whether he was willing to take up a position with it.
—It was Mr Peter Yu, Acting Commissioner.
—The honourable senator says it was Peter Yu who, on behalf of the Aboriginal Development Commission, requested Mr Wyatt to come to Adelaide.
—So did Mr Wyatt say that it was Mr Yu-at the hearing.

—That is all right. In that case it is confirmed. All I am saying is that I reject any notion that is being peddled that the Minister's office, or the Minister personally, was involved in some conspiratorial transaction to get Mr Wyatt over to Adelaide that was not in the normal course of responding to the ADC's request to Mr Wyatt that he consider taking up the position of General Manager.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask the Minister to note that I actually asked him whether Acting Commissioner Perkins was involved in any way with the facilitation or authorisation of Mr Wyatt's travel. I understand that the Minister said that he cannot advise us now. Will he obtain an answer to that question and advise the Senate?
—Of course I will have a look at the question in the Hansard and try to get a particular answer. I will respond, I hope, tomorrow.

—I remind the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce that, having viewed certain documents in 1987, I brought to the attention of all members of both Houses and the Minister that I supported Mr Paul Ritter's contention that his export grant claims were damaged by an allegedly false statement by a public servant which, in turn, was repeated and developed in reports to those making decisions about export development grants. Is the Minister aware that with the completion of the appeal to the High Court of Australia on 27 October 1988, associated with the Export Development Grants Board, his prime objection to a ministerial inquiry has been removed? Will the Minister now hold the inquiry into the clearly documented alleged maladministration, as was the intention of his predecessor in the area, the Hon. John Dawkins, then the Minister for Trade? In the interest of the protection of civil liberties and as the aforementioned alleged maladministration has been drawn to the attention of three successive Ministers-that is Ministers Bowen, Dawkins and Button-repeatedly since 1983, can the Minister expedite the inquiry? Is he aware that the manuscript for Paul Ritter's book Curses from Canberra contains a detailed documented analysis of the matter? Will the Minister advise the Senate what action he will take to ensure that false and misleading reports by public servants will not be allowed to damage citizens in this way in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jenkins is correct. This matter has been going on for a long time. In fact, I wrote to Senator Jenkins about the matter on 18 November 1987. I pointed out in that letter that on 21 August 1984 Mr Ritter was arrested by the Australian Federal Police and charged with offences under section 39 of the Export Market Development Grants Act. Following a jury trial, which was held in February 1986, he was found guilty on four counts of attempting to obtain a grant that was not payable, and sentenced to a total of three years imprisonment, the non-parole period being 18 months. Mr Ritter appealed to the Western Australian Full Court of Criminal Appeal against his conviction which appeal was unanimously dismissed on 5 August 1986. Mr Ritter subsequently sought leave to appeal to the High Court. I said in that letter to Senator Jenkins that in all the circumstances I believed that if Mr Ritter and others wanted a review of the case the best course would be for Mr Ritter to pursue his formal legal options to finality by continuing with his application for leave to appeal. Such a course would necessarily also involve a review by his own counsel of the evidence, the information Mr Ritter has available, and the cases which have already been held.

ANSWER.PARA: If, in the light of such a review, it was considered that there was a case, Mr Ritter could then proceed and the High Court could decide. If not, at least this would be a judgment arrived at by Mr Ritter in consultation with his own counsel. The fact that Mr Ritter has filed a notice of discontinuance and withdrawn his appeal to the High Court does not change the situation.

In part 4 of Senator Jenkins's question I think she asked whether I was aware of a manuscript for Mr Ritter's book Curses from Canberra which allegedly contains the detailed and documented analysis of the matter. I must say that I am not aware of that manuscript and I have not seen it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My question did not relate at all to the trial or the sentence passed upon Mr Ritter. My question related to a public servant's report that was used at the trial and related to misleading quotations within that report and this is my inquiry. Can the Minister please answer the question relating to the misleading evidence of the public servant in the report?

—I am not in a position to comment on evidence given by a public servant at a trial. Senator Jenkins raised a number of points in her original question and I answered them in terms of the legal procedures which had been followed. While there may be an allegation in Mr Ritter's book or somewhere else about what a particular public servant said at the trial, I again remind the honourable senator that this matter was taken to the Full Court in Western Australia on appeal. It was unanimous in its decision in rejecting that appeal. Mr Ritter then sought leave to appeal to the High Court of Australia and abandoned that application for leave to appeal. In my answer I also said that it would probably be helpful if these matters were examined by Mr Ritter with his own counsel. I do not think that any of those things have happened. I am not in a position to comment on the accuracy or otherwise of what may have been said by a public servant as a witness in the trial.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. When the Minister was Minister for Transport and Communications, did he approve or, since that date, has the current Minister approved any program sponsorship for the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS)? Did the Minister or his successor approve the advertising of commercial services and companies which is occurring in conjunction with the broadcast of the test pattern by SBS? When was such approval or approvals given? If no such approvals have been granted, will the current Minister continue to allow the current practice or will SBS be directed to cease the advertising until such approval is given? What rates are the advertisers being charged by SBS and what criteria are being applied by SBS or the Minister to determine the advertising messages that are screened and the companies that are promoted? Finally, will such advertising be capable of scrutiny by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal or will it be immune from standards set by the Tribunal by virtue of the fact that it is being carried on by a government broadcaster?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Broadcasting Service can, of course, have sponsorship under its statute with the approval of the Minister. I have no personal recollection of any such approval being sought from me in the context of test pattern advertising or, to the best of my recollection-I will check this-in any other context. I will certainly check out whether there has been any approval or what the circumstances are of the current test pattern advertising, if such there is, to which Senator Lewis referred.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot, for the life of me, begin to imagine who would be wanting to advertise on the test pattern except, I suppose, in the context of that test pattern being fairly widely used when people seek to tune sets, particularly in the context of aggregation. Maybe there is some commercial rationale for it. I would certainly encourage SBS to derive revenue from whatever source it possibly can but that is a matter for the judgment of the Minister in the circumstances of each particular case.

SBS advertising is, according to my recollection-although it is fading fast on these matters-not subject to scrutiny under the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. That is a matter in issue. The present review of the Broadcasting Tribunal covers whether advertising and indeed other standard matters for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and SBS should be so subject to the disciplines that exist in relation to commercial channels. There are two views on that question as on so many others. I would not seek to pre-empt the Government's consideration of that matter. I will seek further information and give Senator Lewis the best answer I can as soon as I can.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Is the Minister aware of a conference that was held in Sydney on 28 October on the question of natural gas for motor vehicles? What is the Government doing to keep pace with developments in the production of alternative transport fuels and the role of natural gas in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the conference. In fact, at one point I was scheduled to open it but I could not do that, although an opening statement was made on my behalf. Encouraging the use of alternative transport fuels is one part of the Government's policy response to the challenges arising from the decline in domestic production of liquid fuels which is expected over the period to the year 2000. Australia, as honourable senators would know, has large resources of natural gas which provide a major potential source for alternative transport fuels.

ANSWER.PARA: Natural gas as a direct substitute for gasoline and diesel is receiving from us the highest priority because of its short term potential. We also attach a very high priority to research, development and demonstration of other alternative transport fuels such as methanol. Australia is also well advanced on the technology needed to use natural gas as a transport fuel. Last week the first international conference on natural gas vehicles was held in Sydney. Indeed, I understand that on Friday of this week a Trans-Perth bus, that is a bus that takes passengers around metropolitan Perth which is fitted with natural gas fuel injection, will be available in Canberra for inspection. Last week through the Department I announced a package of eight grants totalling $2.65m for projects on natural gas in transport. Those projects are aimed at further developing the technology and demonstrating it to a wide range of potential users. I am particularly pleased at the level of contributions from the private sector and from State governments for the recipients of these grants of some $6.4m, making an all-up total of $9.05m which will be spent on this sort of research. It gives me confidence that the technology we are developing in Australia will lead quickly to tangible results. Increased use of natural gas also has significant environmental benefits.
Natural gas contributes less to the greenhouse effect than gasoline and diesel. When natural gas is used in diesel engines particulate emissions, that is the smoke emissions, are greatly reduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to recent reports that the Government is contemplating a scheme which will require employers with more than five staff to contribute up to 2 per cent of their payroll towards work force training. Is this an indication that there will be further cuts in spending on education and that these cuts will occur in areas of trade related educational courses? The report also indicates that the industry funded schemes will have representatives of employees, unions and educational bodies controlling them but no mention is made of employers who will contribute to the scheme. Is there any substance to these reports of measures which will further limit the profitability of Australian small business?

—The Government is concerned in taking up an issue that has been neglected by probably all previous governments in Australia, and that is to ensure that there is an adequate training effort, an issue which has probably become more important over time. There have been some Government discussions on the matter. I am not going to comment on the veracity or otherwise of the latest rumour that is being peddled in some publication or on the electronic media. We will be making a statement about the Government's decision in due course.

—My question is directed to the Minister, representing the Attorney-General. Given that a number of provisions of the Companies Code may have been breached by Rothwells Ltd bank at a time when it was being financially sponsored by the Western Australian Government, including provisions dealing with the ability of the company to repay its debts as and when they fell due and provisions for bad and doubtful debts, and given the serious effect this matter is having on the national securities market, I ask: Why has the Minister not, pursuant to section 291 of the code, instructed the National Companies and Securities Commission to conduct an inquiry into the affairs of the bank?

—The short answer is that I do not see why he would need to in the sense that, as I am advised, the National Companies and Securities Commission is already undertaking investigations into the events surrounding Rothwells and, as I understand it--
—Is that right?

—So I am advised, and the investigations are going on. As far as I know, the need for the Commonwealth Minister to intervene is not there. Indeed, as I understand it, that particular section has never been used by a Commonwealth Minister to intervene in these matters.

—At Question Time today Senator Jenkins asked me a question relating to Mr Paul Ritter. In answering that question I said that I was not familiar with the manuscript of his book, which I think is called Curses from Canberra. I want to qualify that answer by saying that since I answered the question I have become aware that a copy of that manuscript has been made available to me and I will certainly look at it, without any detraction from the answer I gave at Question Time that I would be pleased to look at it, because, apart from anything else, when I knew Mr Ritter I had a very high personal regard for him as a town planner and innovator.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 October Senator Alston asked me a series of questions about Australian assistance to Afghanistan in which reference was made to a $20,000 contribution to the Australian Red Cross Society to assist in providing the services of an Australian surgical nurse for a Red Cross hospital treating war victims in Kabul, Afghanistan. He asked me to explain on what possible basis my predecessor had claimed that the hospital would be open without discrimination to all those wounded in the present conflict.

ANSWER.PARA: I can confirm that the Government has provided these funds and, after initial difficulties in getting the operation under way, the hospital commenced operations on 1 October 1988 with the services of Sister Margaret Staff of Wodonga, Victoria. I can also inform Senator Alston that the hospital is being run solely by the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC); that the ICRC has a written understanding, in the form of an exchange of letters with the authorities in Kabul, about the operations of the hospital; that the ICRC regards patients seeking treatment at the hospital as under its protection and therefore entitled to return whence they came unimpeded; and that although ICRC would not refuse to treat any wounded person who arrived at the hospital, ICRC expects that combatants from either side would be treated elsewhere. Senator Alston also asked me whether it was a fact that the Government did not expect to spend any of its $20m contribution, which has been allocated to phase one of the United Nations returnee program for Afghan refugees, in the current financial year. For instance, we read at paragraph 3.11:

Two branches of the very party which introduced the system had to be formally reminded of their reporting obligations.

I remind the Senate that when we were debating it we had statements from a number of people. I shall quote from Senator Robert Ray, and Senator Macklin for the Australian Democrats, to illustrate how it was thought that we might get a quite different approach from that which the Committee chose to adopt. For example, Senator Robert Ray said that he did not want the inquiry to go ahead. In Hansard of 16 March 1988 on page 816 he said:

. . . if it does go ahead, I will not be bitterly disappointed. I look forward to Mr Strickland coming to give evidence. I hope he is truthful; I have no reason to believe otherwise. I want him to give evidence and I want questions to be asked. I will not be able to ask them because I am not on the Committee, but I hope someone will.

He listed the things that he wanted to hear about this incident. More importantly though, when one looks at how the Australian Democrats reacted to the amendment moved by Senator Collins, one finds Senator Macklin making it clear that he believed that there would be an approach by the Committee which involved its calling evidence from that relevant party. I had already pointed out in the Senate that I did not think Senator Collins's amendment was the best way of ensuring that the Privileges Committee looked at the real difficulties which the particular case raised. I said that it would be far too easy on a generalised reference to take the simple view that if something was defamatory it should not be circulated. That is far too neat for the issues raised in the present case. We have a situation which requires that we ensure that somebody is not denied his rights to come to this Parliament by the use of the threat of legal proceedings which economics preclude being determined by the courts. I put very squarely before the Senate that that was the danger of this approach. Senator Macklin responded on that and answered my point. He said:

I note that his motion did not require the Standing Committee of Privileges to call either Strickland or Burke. In fact, the Committee can do what it likes. It would be very odd not to have them called, I admit, but it would have no obligation and no requirement to call them. In fact, it would not even have a requirement to tell them that a hearing was being conducted.
That is his reference to the original motion I had moved-that there was no specific obligation on the Committee to call Strickland or Burke. Senator Macklin went on to say:

Some of the members of the Committee have been sitting in the chamber throughout the entire debate and are very much aware of what the issues are. I believe it would be very odd to go into a general inquiry without looking at that specific item.

That was the attitude adopted by the Australian Democrats. What happened is that when the Committee sat-all this is contained in the report-Senator Teague moved that the Committee of Privileges invite Mr R. M. Strickland to appear before the Committee. Senator Durack and Senator Teague voted in favour of that. Senator Giles, Senator Childs, Senator Coates and Senator Powell of the Australian Democrats voted against it. So, the particular issue was not dealt with. The questions that Senator Ray suggested might be asked of Mr Strickland could not be asked.

What this enabled the majority of the Committee to do was to avoid completely the issue which I raised in the Senate. I did not raise the issue that there should be some general justification of the circulation of defamatory material under the guise of a petition. I raised the issue of what the position is if a citizen of limited means circulates a proper petition but is pushed off course by the threat of legal proceedings from a person with a much longer pocket, someone who is richer. I suggested to the Senate that we should be concerned about protecting the rights of citizens. I admitted that there was a conflict of two principles, but I said that it was worth examining how those principles ought to work and that the Committee of Privileges was the appropriate body to do that.

I pay tribute to the fast footwork of Senator Collins. I make no imputation against him in using that expression. He very cleverly diverted this matter from an examination of a particular and difficult point which gave rise to the issue I have just described into a general inquiry. The Committee then chose not to deal with the complexity of the issue which had been raised. I very much regret that. This is one of those occasions when I express my personal disappointment at the performance of the Senate and at the attitude of the majority of the Committee. I think it is true that in an increasingly complex society it is more and more difficult for the ordinary man or woman, the person of limited means, to raise a case against the powerful. This is a matter which, I would have thought, would have brought forward the natural concerns of members of the Australian Labor Party who once were concerned with such matters. But I think that in this case party politics have triumphed and the issue simply has not been dealt with by the Committee.

I have considered whether there is some alternative action that I can take. I do not believe that there is. But I say, in particular to the Australian Democrats and Senator Powell, who is in this chamber at the moment, that it is a matter of enormous disappointment to me that she did not follow the very reasonable approach which was adopted by Senator Macklin when he supported the Collins amendment. I believe that she was, therefore, a party to ensuring that this matter was not properly considered.

I did not mind Mr Strickland being put to the test. Mr Strickland sought some advice from me and he got it, as any constituent would have got it. There were inferences and suggestions that he was not bona fide. That could have been put to the test. All I say is that he has not had his day in court. He did not get his day in court when the ex-Premier threatened him with legal action, because he could not afford it. He did not get his day in court here because we took a partisan attitude to a matter which I think should have been dealt with quite differently.

As I say, as a long time defender of the Senate and as somebody who has opposed constitutional amendments which I believed would have diminished the standing and capacity of the Senate to do its job, this is one of those occasions when I am not proud of the Senate at all. I thought it was a very second rate performance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In closing this debate I would like to recapitulate a few of the circumstances which brought this matter before the Senate in the first place. The petition which was the genesis of the whole reference effectively questioned the fitness of the ex-Premier of Western Australia to be appointed to the position, which he now holds with distinction, of Ambassador to Ireland and to the Holy See. However, as Senator Chaney has explained, this was not the question which was before the Committee of Privileges to determine. The Committee had the benefit of the wisdom of the Senate in the course of the debate which resulted in the reference that came to us. The Committee had the responsibility of determining just how that reference would be dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: We dealt with the matter without acrimony. Although there was a minority report, it was a thoughtful report. The majority of the Committee believed that it was mistaken. We agreed to differ in the best tradition of the Senate, without any histrionics or ill-feeling. Imagine my surprise, therefore, when the Committee reported on the last night of sitting in the provisional Parliament House, to find that we came under quite vicious attack from Senator Chaney.

At that time I seriously considered asking for Senator Chaney to be called to order for the intemperance of his criticism of the Privileges Committee and the way in which we had carried out the reference. It is not surprising that Senator Chaney rejected the conclusion of the Committee, but for him to be so critical of the manner of our deliberations seemed to me to be bordering on the unparliamentary. His language again this afternoon has been somewhat pushing the bounds of the conventions, at least, of this chamber. Our last night of sitting in the provisional Parliament House was not one for recrimination. Once again, the agile wit of Senator Collins helped good humour to be retrieved, and good sense prevailed. The closing stages of those sittings of the Senate were conducted with a considerable amount of tolerance and a capacity to work together which so often characterise this place.
The Committee had the option of dealing with the principle involved which certainly was the matter before us, and which reads:

. . . whether the circulation of a petition containing defamatory material for the purpose of gaining signatures and subsequent submission to the Senate is or ought to be privileged and how such issues should be determined and in what forum.

It had the option of doing a case study of the incident which engendered the reference. It had the option of doing both. The debate in the Senate, as Senator Chaney has quite correctly observed, canvassed the way in which the matter might be dealt with. It is gratuitous, however, for any member of the Senate to assert that a debate of that nature should be taken as part of the reference, as it were, that was before us, which seems to me to be the position which Senator Chaney has taken.

Most of the submissions that we received addressed the principle, taking the view that the principle was the matter that should be dealt with. But more importantly, the majority of the Committee was persuaded by the fact that the Senate, given the choice of supporting the original motion, which would have been the study of that particular case, or Senator Collins's amendment, had opted for the latter.

Perhaps a case study would have provided a more compelling theatrical performance, a three-ring circus, with lots of press attention and endless telephoto opportunities for various members of the Senate. But the Committee, in its wisdom, decided that the substance of the question was worthy of serious consideration-that it was of considerable importance-without the distraction of partisan politics and colourful personalities to the extent that this was possible, and ably assisted by the Deputy Clerk, Anne Lynch, I believe that we produced a useful and non-partisan report which makes a contribution to the specialised field of privileges law. A number of those who have taken part in subsequent debate in the Senate have mentioned that previously privileges law has been based on cases. I do not believe that that fact makes any difference to the value of our report. The way in which we dealt with this matter of principle was totally correct. It produced a well thought out and well expressed report, one that has received a considerable amount of favourable attention. I believe that the conduct of the Committee was totally correct. I believe that to question that conduct is totally beyond the bounds of Senate convention.

I would like to finish this debate on a very positive note. As I have said before, the conduct of the Committee itself was positive and constructive. The Committee dealt with the substance of the matter that was before it in an honourable and effective way. I would like to pay tribute to those people who were involved in the Committee and who made the report the useful precedent that I believe it is. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE ADMINISTRATION OF ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs relating to the protection of witnesses.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The report arises from a responsibility imposed upon Senate committees by clause (18) of resolution 1 of the resolutions of the Senate concerning parliamentary privileges carried on 25 February 1988, which reads:

Where a committee has any reason to believe that any person has been improperly influenced in respect of evidence which may be given before the committee, or has been subjected to or threatened with penalty or injury in respect of any evidence given, the committee shall take all reasonable steps to ascertain the facts of the matter. Where the committee considers that the facts disclose that a person may have been improperly influenced or subjected to or threatened with a penalty or injury in respect of evidence which may be or has been given before the committee, the committee shall report the facts and its conclusions to the Senate.

Although this has been a difficult matter, I believe that all the Committee members-there were representatives from the four parties-took their responsibilities with regard to this matter very seriously, and I am pleased that eventually we have come forward with a unanimous report. But I must say that that unanimity was not easily achieved. I understand that this is the first time that a matter has come before the Senate arising from this resolution. I want to explain briefly how I, as Chairman of the Committee, saw our role, and I think this is a view that was accepted by the Committee as a whole. I saw our role as conducting a preliminary examination of the matter to determine whether an arguable case existed. I do not want to be excessively legalistic in this matter but I think that was the approach we took, and, as the resolution states, we then had to report to the Senate. I saw the purpose of our exercise-and I think the Committee as a whole did-as assisting the Senate, and in particular Mr President, in the task of determining whether a matter should be referred to the Senate Standing Committee of Privileges. We dealt with the matter by looking at written material-and we would have looked at other sorts of records had they been available-but not by calling witnesses. We did not believe that it was appropriate that there should be, in effect, two privileges inquiries into this matter-one by the Senate Select Committee and, if we so concluded, a subsequent inquiry by the Privileges Committee itself.

Although I am concerned about some parts of the conclusions that the Committee has come to, and I will make some comments about the nature of the precedent that they might create, I believe that it would have been worse to have had a partisan division in the Committee in regard to this matter or to have left the way open for allegations that Government senators were endeavouring to conduct some sort of cover-up. Although this report in itself is a fairly minor document, it occurs within the context of some major controversy taking place in related areas and, therefore, it is relevant that we should be cognisant of that circumstance.

I wish to make some brief comments on the merits of the matter. There were two separate questions that the Committee had to deal with relating to two witnesses that came before it. The matters are related politically but they are not related in terms of their substance for potential consideration by the Privileges Committee and for the consideration of this report. The second in time sequence but the first in terms of the consideration of the Committee and the presentation of the report relates to Mrs Shirley McPherson, who is called by the quaint name of Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). On 2 September she came before the Committee as a witness and, although she indicated on that occasion that she was Chairman of that Commission, she appeared as an individual and that was made clear to everybody present. At a subsequent ADC Board meeting on 10 October a resolution of no confidence was carried. That is outlined in the report. The relevant extract in paragraph 12 refers to Mrs McPherson making public comments, notwithstanding a resolution of the Commission which required her to notify the Commission prior to making public statements. I think this indicates quite clearly the confusion that underpins the subsequent actions of the ADC which led to the need for this report. The resolution of the ADC Board of 23 May, which is referred to in that no confidence motion, does not refer to the question of prior notification at all; it refers to the requirement for prior approval of the Board of Commissioners before a submission or public statement is made. Of course, for the purposes of our consideration today there is a significant difference between notification and approval.

I do not think there is a great deal of doubt that any organisation is entitled to require people to notify it about public statements they may be going to make. But it is entirely different to say that, before one proceeds, one has to seek the approval of this Board, particularly in the circumstances where it could be seen as limiting an individual's right to appear in an individual capacity. I think it is perfectly open to interpret the decision of the Commission as in no way intending to limit the rights of individuals, and it has subsequently indicated that that is what it meant. Nevertheless, it is an interpretation that is open. I am not aware of anybody saying that it is not the right of any organisation to require approval of any submission made in its name. Any organisation with which I have ever been associated would always require a report made in the name of that organisation to have the approval of the responsible body authorised to give such approval. But it would not indicate the right to limit my or, in this instance, Mrs McPherson's, right as an individual to appear as a witness before a Senate select committee. So it is open to being interpreted as improper interference in terms of section 4 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act.

There may be no sufficient penalty or constraint involved in the actions concerned as to constitute substantial obstruction in terms of the resolutions of the Senate, nevertheless it is capable of some other interpretation. In fact, it is capable, as I have said, of quite straightforward explanation. The ADC's letter of 20 October referred to the resolution passed at the sixty-second Commission meeting, which it forwarded to the President and which Mr President tabled. It informed the Senate that the resolution:
was not intended to in any way encroach upon or limit the powers of the Senate or any Parliamentary Committee;
was not intended to prevent or in any way affect the right of individuals to appear before the Senate or such Committees;

was purely an administrative mechanism designed to ensure that papers and submissions presented on behalf of the ADC contained information that was accurate and reflected the views of the Commission . . .

I think it was a resolution carried after the event. Perhaps it is not such a surprising resolution for it to carry but it is a perfectly logical and straightforward explanation of how the circumstances could have arisen. The Committee had to accept the obvious fact that the sequence of events was capable of an interpretation which would lead to an arguable case of breach of privilege. Whether we thought it might have been a minor breach or a technical breach it was certainly an arguable case that it could have been a breach of privilege and therefore there was no difficulty in the Committee obtaining agreement that the matter should be referred to the Privileges Committee.

Mr O'Brien's case was different. He appeared before the Committee as a witness some two months earlier on 19 July-ultimately as an individual. Although it is not relevant for the purposes of this discussion, he did seek at one stage to appear as the General Manager but that was subsequently not approved. He appeared, as I said, on 19 July. The ADC met on 22 July and no action was taken, although it must have been aware that Mr O'Brien had appeared as it was well publicised. The ADC met again in August and no action was taken in regard to Mr O'Brien's appearance. In October, at the third meeting after his appearance, Mr O'Brien was transferred to another position. Technically, he was transferred at the same level, to a position of equal rank, but I think-this is not a point we need to resolve for the purposes of this report-it is arguable that he suffered a penalty in the terms of the privileges resolution of this Parliament. I would not want to be called upon at this stage to make that determination, but it is an arguable proposition should it become relevant.

There is in my view, and I think in the view of my colleagues on this side of the House, no evidence at this stage of a link between Mr O'Brien's appearance before the Committee and the subsequent decision of the ADC. If my very vague recollection of the Latin saying is appropriate, it is what is called a post hoc, ergo propter hoc fallacy-because it followed something therefore it was caused by it. I do not believe that that argument has as yet been established. But there is a clear determination by some senators to pursue the matter and they put forward their arguments in a reasonable and cogent manner before the Committee. There was indeed an unsatisfactory-it might be described as a too smart by half reply-by the Aboriginal Development Commission in explaining the decision which it made which was of no assistance to the Committee in trying to resolve the matter. So on the basis of those two events, to ensure that not only is justice done but also it is seen to be done, at a meeting this morning the Committee unanimously agreed to refer the O'Brien matter as well to the Privileges Committee. I take this opportunity of thanking my colleagues Senator Collins and Senator Devlin for agreeing to that proposal. It was not easy for them, given their views on the question, which I think are similar to mine, but I appreciate their action on it. It led to a unanimous decision which was worth while and appropriate, and served the interests of the Parliament.

In conclusion, I wish to say some things that might assist future committees in their consideration of similar matters. As I said, I understand that this is the first time a matter has come forward in this way by way of a committee exercising its responsibilities arising from the Senate's privileges resolution earlier this year. I think it would be the unanimous view of all senators, past and present, that privilege is a very serious matter. For citizens, referral of their actions to the Privileges Committee is a very substantial step, and not one that should be taken at whim or lightly. There should be at least some evidence before a committee refers a matter to the Privileges Committee for further examination. I am not proposing a change in the process. I believe the process on which we agreed is appropriate, that is, that we conduct only a preliminary inquiry, but the level of connection needs to be of sufficient substance to warrant a referral. I do not believe that citizens take lightly the question of having their actions referred to the Privileges Committee and I would never want to get to the situation where they might.

It is not appropriate that any future committee should look at our action and the statements that have been made about it and in some way interpret that it is appropriate to refer to the Privileges Committee matters so that the Committee might conduct some sort of fishing expedition just in case there is a bit of evidence floating around somewhere. I make those remarks while supporting the Committee's recommendations that both matters should be referred to the Privileges Committee. As I have said, I think the ADC letter of 20 October which I read to the Senate earlier sets the context in which this matter should best be examined. I suspect that it is probably more of a misunderstanding than anything else. But to ensure the very important protection of the privileges of this Parliament, to ensure that no-one is in any doubt that he cannot interfere with the right of any Australian citizen to appear before any parliamentary committee, the Committee recommends the referral. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs is not reporting today on the reference given to it by the Senate to investigate certain matters in relation to the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. That report is due to be brought down on 23 February 1989. We are reporting now on certain matters which have occurred during the taking of evidence by the Select Committee. The issue was simply whether two witnesses who came before that Committee have been penalised subsequently in ways which constitute a breach of the privilege of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has set out in the report, which the Chairman of the Committee tabled a moment ago, the relevant statutory provisions which cover the protection of witnesses and which make certain behaviour towards witnesses an offence. It is not the function of the Select Committee to determine matters of privilege; rather the Committee is required by resolution of the Senate to make known to the Senate any occurrences which it thinks might constitute a breach of privilege. The Senate, as honourable senators know, altered its procedures last year and this is the first occasion on which a committee has reported on a matter as provided for under the new arrangements and therefore requiring appropriate action by the Senate.

The function of the Standing Committee of Privileges is to inquire into and report upon complaints of privilege which may be referred to it by the Senate. It is to the Committee of Privileges that this matter will go for determination. I do not intend to try to determine it. It is common ground within the Select Committee that certain matters in relation to the treatment of Mrs Shirley McPherson should be referred to the Privileges Committee for determination and report. The Chairman has outlined what they are and I hope that such a reference will be made. It is in relation to the treatment of Mr Mick O'Brien, also a witness before the Select Committee, that opinions vary. The Liberal and National party senators and the Australian Democrats senators believe that there is sufficient doubt about the treatment of Mr O'Brien by the commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission to justify his matter being referred to the Privileges Committee.

Government senators have agreed to this course of action being taken as the Chairman has set out and the Committee has so recommended. I believe that the case in relation to Mr O'Brien is stronger than would have been indicated by the Chairman in his remarks a moment ago. The facts are that Mr O'Brien gave evidence to the Select Committee and that he provided documents which were prepared under a delegation he held. They were documents which had been approved by the Chairperson, Mrs Shirley McPherson. The facts are that these were challenged by certain acting commissioners and that they were withdrawn. Later, Mr O'Brien was removed from his position as General Manager of the ADC and transferred to a new and artificial position in a process which itself is now the subject of legal proceedings. It is a fact that Mr O'Brien is now on special leave, that he is unlikely to return to the ADC and that these are all matters for concern.

I do not intend further to refer to the matters which may be the subject of legal action. We assert that, on balance, the commissioners of the ADC, most of them acting commissioners, link Mick O'Brien and Shirley McPherson in their criticisms. We further assert that they were furious with them both for appearing before the Senate Select Committee, that they dealt with Shirley McPherson one way and with Mick O'Brien another way. The real reason, we believe, for removing Mick O'Brien from the job of General Manager of the ADC was to punish him, inter alia, for appearing before the Senate Select Committee. We asked the ADC for an explanation of the move. The explanation, a copy of which is attached to our report, was in Public Service jargon. It answered nothing and it was an insult. I believe that Mick O'Brien still has much important evidence to give to the Select Committee whose work is far from complete. He can only give evidence, as can Shirley McPherson, if the Senate in turn gives to them the protection they require and deserve against crude reprisals. It is necessary that Mr Mick O'Brien's matter also be referred to the Privileges Committee for its attention.

I observe that an apology like that sent to us by the ADC in relation to Mrs McPherson in no way vitiates any original breach of privilege. As I said, this is the first time that the new Senate procedures have been used and will be tested. Many potential witnesses will watch the outcome closely. There are many Senate committees carrying out their tasks and many potential witnesses who have to make a decision as to whether it is proper and safe for them to offer themselves to give evidence before a Senate committee. Our duty is to offer protection and to respond to breaches; especially breaches against employees and individuals who have acted bravely and in the public interest. I commend the report of the Select Committee on this matter. I indicate that we hope that appropriate procedural steps will be taken by Mr President to ensure that both these matters go to the Committee of Privileges as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague, Senator Peter Baume, on this very important report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs entitled Protection of Witnesses. As the Senate will recall, last week the President of the Senate commissioned the Senate Committee to produce a report as to whether there was any breach of privilege in relation to two witnesses, Mrs McPherson and Mr O'Brien. It is important to note that the Committee has brought down a unanimous report although Senator McMullan has some slight differences with the report. Nevertheless, irrespective of Senator McMullan's comments in the Senate, the report was unanimous-agreed to by all the senators who were involved on that Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Select Committee has agreed that both the Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), Mrs Shirley McPherson, and the General Manager, Mr Mick O'Brien, could have some penalty inflicted on them in retaliation for their appearance before the Senate Select Committee. In the case of Mrs McPherson, who is the Chairperson of the ADC, a motion of no confidence was moved against her at the meeting of the Aboriginal Development Commission which met in Adelaide on 10 to 14 October.

Mrs McPherson appeared before the Senate Select Committee as a private individual. She made it very clear that her appearance before the Senate Select Committee was as an individual. Yet on 14 October at the Adelaide conference of the ADC a motion of no confidence was carried against Mrs McPherson. It began by saying that the Chairman appeared before the Senate Select Committee on 2 September 1988 and it then went on to other matters. That, I would have thought, could have been a breach of privilege.

As Senator McMullan indicated, we unanimously agreed that that case of Mrs Shirley McPherson should be investigated by the Privileges Committee. At the same ADC meeting in Adelaide a resolution was also passed creating a Senior Executive Service (SES) level 3 position. A temporary position was established at an SES level. It was recommended that the current General Manager, Mr O'Brien, be placed in the created position forthwith. Mr Cedric Wyatt was to be transferred to the position of Acting General Manager. A decision to create a temporary SES level 2 position was taken and so forth. I will table that resolution.

We believe that constituted a very similar case. Whereas on 14 October a vote of no confidence was passed in relation to Mrs McPherson, Mr O'Brien at the same meeting was removed from his official position. Mr O'Brien believed that he was wrongly dismissed or wrongly removed. He has taken legal action against this decision. The ADC also provided an explanation as to Mr O'Brien's transfer. It reads:

Members of the Board regard Mr O'Brien as being the most suitably qualified ADC officer to discharge effectively the duties of the newly created position. This placement was considered by Members of the Board as a show of confidence in Mr O'Brien.

One could not get two more conflicting statements. Mr O'Brien believes he was denied natural justice by this move and the ADC said that he was given the carrot because he was the most qualified officer. That is a decision that the Privileges Committee must look into. It is not one that we on the Senate Select Committee were given the right from this Senate to investigate. We were merely asked by the Senate to establish whether there was a prima facie case to bring before the Privileges Committee. We believed that there was. On this side of the House the Australian Democrats, the Liberals and the Nationals believed that there was a case to answer.

On 14 October 1988 Mrs McPherson, acting as chairwoman, in answer to a query from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Hon. Gerry Hand, told the Minister in writing that Mr O'Brien no longer held his position with the ADC. Yet I understand that Mr O'Brien is still the General Manager of the ADC. The matter of Mr O'Brien's sacking and reinstatement to his present position is absolutely confusing, to say the least. I understand that he has been sacked or removed-whichever term one likes to use-reinstated, replaced again, and at the moment he is on leave. This also is a matter that the Privileges Committee must investigate. I do not believe it is up to the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs to establish whether Mr O'Brien was sacked, transferred or paid a penalty for appearing before the Committee. That is a matter for the Privileges Committee to establish, and it is my personal belief that the matter can be determined only by the Privileges Committee and by moving to ensure that Mr O'Brien's account of the events is fully available to the Senate and his rights in this matter fully protected.

I have already stated that we in the Senate are debating today a most serious matter, one of a type that rarely comes before the Senate, and I believe we have to be extremely cautious. We have to make sure that when people appear before a Senate committee to give evidence their position is absolutely protected. We in this Parliament represent the people of Australia and we, in turn, in the interests of public disclosure and public interest, must give those people who wish to give evidence the ultimate protection. I believe this cause can be served only if Mr O'Brien and Mrs McPherson have the right to have their case considered before the Privileges Committee. I also believe that this matter should be investigated with the utmost haste so that a conclusion can be reached by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take up one item Senator McMullan mentioned. He dwelt considerably on the gravity of referring an item to the Privileges Committee, pointing out that this very significant step was not one to be taken lightly. I reinforce the remarks Senator Boswell has just made and point out that as this is the highest parliament in the land, as this Parliament has seen fit to set up Senate select committees and standing committees to investigate a wide range of matters of public importance, it is absolutely vital that those committees not be impeded in any way in the carrying out of their functions and that therefore there should be an absolute guarantee of protection for witnesses who appear before those committees. I would weigh against the matter of gravity Senator McMullan has raised the equally important matter of gravity of the protection of witnesses.
—No-one is disputing that.

—I am just placing emphasis in a slightly different direction. I think this matter is of considerable importance. I think there is a prima facie case, as has been indicated by the two Opposition speakers so far. I think there is a sufficient case to answer in this matter with respect to Mr O'Brien and that his case should be referred to the Privileges Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: ``After item 123, the following item is inserted:

`123aa.
