Nos. 1
to 9
`(2) Parts for goods covered by sub-item (1)
Nos. 1

The argument that I wish to present here is one which, as the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has been advised, I have presented before but which I intend to present until I get some satisfactory response from the Government. The circumstances I am talking about are ones which tend to arise more and more. The reason for this is that up to now those goods which are sales tax exempt and are being used by disabled people are essentially chosen by the Department, but they are also goods which have been specifically manufactured for disabled people. I am not talking about that category of items; I am talking about a totally different category of items. I ask honourable senator to think about the research and development costs which are necessary in the development of a specific item for disabled people. Those costs are large, and because the number of sales is relatively small the item itself is very costly. It makes eminent sense-and every government has done it-to remove sales tax there.

However, there is another series of items which are not manufactured for disabled people but are manufactured for all-for example, computers. There is no way in the world that a research and development program will be undertaken by any company in relation to specific computers for disabled people. Some of the major companies such as IBM Ltd, Apple Computer Pty Ltd and others have undertaken specific research and development projects on peripherals for disabled people in the use of computers. However, the essential computer item which is necessary still has sales tax on it.

I will outline some of the situations in which people might find themselves. The example that first kindled my interest in this matter was that of a child who was born with thalidomide problems, with his hands attached to his shoulders. His hands were operational. That child-and thank goodness this is now the case in our society-attends a normal school, not a special school. But obviously he has enormous difficulty in doing the other things that kids in the class do, such as painting, drawing and writing. A number of people from universities and various associations concerned with disabled people, banded together and actually came up with a method of dividing a standard keyboard into two and mounting it on special brackets so that that child was able to use the machine. The child used that machine for a few months prior to school and then wished to take it to school. That was also accomplished and that child is now doing well in school.

Interestingly enough, the commercial operators who sold that computer to the parents took no profit because they discovered that they could not sell it to that disabled child without sales tax being imposed. The reason I mention the way the commercial operators reacted is that they had that gut feeling that it was really a pretty low exercise to impose the tax and they were willing to forgo their own profits so that the family could get that device for the child. Retailers are in the business of making profits and I do not want to knock them for that. I think it is interesting to note that they were willing to forgo that profit because of a gut feeling about this exercise.

The Department on previous occasions has come up with a number of reasons why this might not be able to be done. The chief one amongst those is that the Department believes that it is a better judge of what is useful for disabled people than those people are themselves. I totally reject that and, interestingly, the Government itself has rejected it. As a result of legislation passed in this place, I think three years ago, under the then Minister for Community Services Grimes, a new philosophy on disabled people was put in place. That was not the previous patronising philosophy but a philosophy whereby, at the direction of disabled people, we would try to make sure that they could live their lives as independently and productively as possible in the way that they wished to live them, not the way that some Department wished them to live them.

So, my amendment involves a philosophical approach. The approach is in keeping with the new Act, which is now operational and which will have completed its implementation phase by the end of next year. My amendment is completely in keeping with the philosophy the Government espoused through the Department. I believe that the Australian Taxation Office ought to espouse the same philosophy. It is the Tax Office which decides which items are useful to disabled people and which are not-not the Department of Community Services and Health, or anybody else. It is the officers in the Tax Office who make the decisions as to disabled people, rather than following the new philosophy which the Government has implemented-and quite rightly implemented-and which the Democrats wholeheartedly support, whereby the disabled themselves take control over their own lives and circumstances.

Certain computer software-almost totally commercially available, not specially written software-is widely used now in many of the organisations which work with the learning disabled. It is used in many schools by students with learning disabilities, and in special schools. Some types of software are used for cause and effect activities, for example, with severely intellectually disabled students. Many new adventure packages are coming onto the market which enable people to move individually through learning courses. I suggest that honourable senators, if they have the opportunity, visit some of the places that are using computers with the learning disabled. They will see the remarkable progress those people are able to make by being able to work individually with the computers. At the end of the exercise they often produce a high quality document-quite unlike anything else they have been able to produce before. It is an enormous boost to their morale.

For the sensory disabled, computer speech in association with pictures on screens is now available, as are braille-to-print or print-to-braille conversion mechanisms. Many of these items are not specifically devised for blind people. Most of the hardware and software in a braille-to-print or print-to-braille conversion mechanism is commercially available. Only a very small part of the software component is specifically written for that purpose.

I have already raised one matter with regard to the physically disabled. A major point is that most of the peripherals and technologies which are being used seek, in whatever way they can, to fool the computer into thinking that it is being controlled by some other mechanism, such as a keyboard, a joy- stick, a mouse or whatever else. Computers are being operated by voice commands or by the movement of the head, the eyes or some other part of the physically disabled person's body. A great deal of work is being done in this area. I have raised this matter before. Last year the Opposition said that it wanted some time to consider the proposal. It has had a year in which to do so. I circulated my amendment to the Opposition about three weeks ago so that it would have forewarning that the matter was being raised again. It is a matter which we have to come to grips with. It is no good any longer simply to say, `We will let the Department make up its mind as to what it will do in these areas'.

Since the debate on this issue last year I have discussed it exhaustively with various community groups that work with disabled people. I have the unanimous support of those groups. They are all very much aware that, with the development of technology, we will see coming onto the general public market more and more items which may be used to enormous advantage by disabled people. It will not involve just computers. There will be many other technological developments. We are in a new phase. We are not talking about a small company somewhere developing specific goods for a specific clientele. We are talking about enormous amounts of money being spent on developing high tech products that will be of enormous benefit to disabled people.

All I am asking is that, in a Budget in which this Government has been willing to lose $400m on what I have characterised as the promotion of alcoholism, we could very well consider my proposal, a proposal which would have very small and very controlled cost consequences. It would involve only those items whose use as special aids a medical practitioner or qualified or registered occupational therapist has certified as necessary. In other words, it would leave the way open for medical practitioners to be able to say in respect of one of their patients, `This person would benefit enormously from having access to and use of these goods and the family is able to purchase them'. Under those circumstances I do not believe that we should be seeking to make a profit out of the exercise.

Again I cite the instance that got me involved in this area in the first place. It was interesting to note that in that case the commercial operators also did not want to make a profit out of selling the goods. They believed that that was not the type of thing that ought to be done. I appeal to honourable senators yet again to give serious consideration to this proposal. It is a very moderate proposal and well in keeping with the Government's own philosophy on the delivery of services to disabled people. My amendment has been couched in a form which complies with all the other provisions in part 1 of the schedule concerned with the delivery of goods to disabled people and the removal of sales tax from those goods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

The proposal is to put some control over it by having a certificate from a medical practitioner, or an occupational therapist, and so on. Obviously that complicates the administration quite significantly and, as Senator Messner suggested, it is not entirely free from the prospect of abuse. Let me make it very clear: this is not a comment about the medical profession in general, but there are doctors who will sign almost anything that is put in front of them in regard to compensation. Of course, doctors, including officials of the Australian Medical Association (AMA), privately acknowledge this, although I understand that they are reluctant to acknowledge it publicly. If there are doctors who are willing to do that, those same doctors would be able to establish a bit of a profitable sideline by also signing these sorts of certificates for anybody who asked them-and this is in addition to the administrative complications.

I think that, unpopular though people who are specialists in tax policy may be, the tax policy questions are better left principally to the Australian Taxation Office or the taxation policy division of the Treasury rather than the AMA. Senator Macklin's proposal would not leave it to the AMA but would leave it to individual medical practitioners, which I suggest would be even worse.

I have already covered the equity provision. Let me recapitulate briefly. If the case is as compelling as Senator Macklin suggests, this is fiddling around at the margins and it does not address the core issue anyway. In addition, it complicates the administration of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act and it is open to abuse.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister's response appears to be dealing with another area, not with the sales tax legislation or the principles on which that is based. We are dealing with the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. Already under this legislation there is the recognised principle that we do not impose a taxation burden on persons who are already disadvantaged in a way different from that of the normal population. We are talking here about persons who, for one reason or other, are physically or mentally handicapped. What the Minister's response is really going to is another area altogether, I agree with him: whether support should be given specifically to persons with handicaps in another way. But here we are talking about the exemptions that ought to apply. Those exemptions already apply in respect of disabled persons. Surely all we are doing is seeking to extend that logically to have regard to modern technology. In those circumstances it is a matter that deserves the support of the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think a couple of points that the Minister raised are worthwhile taking up. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) alleged that if these amendments were passed, it would simply be tinkering around the margins-I think he used the words `fiddling around the margins'. In fact, this whole Bill tinkers around at the margins. That is the purpose of this exercise. Every time we have a sales tax exemptions and classifications Bill before us it is because we are tinkering at yet another margin. Sooner or later I hope that we run out of margins or out of the capacity to tinker. We keep talking about getting rid of anomalies and we just introduce more of them. We talk about not making life difficult for people who are already in difficulties, and we keep on doing it. Even if we were just tinkering at the margins, surely this margin is worth tinkering at.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially the Minister said that if people can afford to pay for a computer, they can afford to pay the sales tax. He said that 10 per cent or 20 per cent of the ultimate purchase price is sales tax, and, presumably, if people can afford the 80 per cent to 90 per cent, they can afford the additional 10 per cent to 20 per cent. That is true of everything. Even if it were not, it is hardly a justifiable argument. Maybe-just maybe-for some parents who are not on the incomes that people in this place are, that 10 per cent or 20 per cent is just too much for them to be able to afford that item. Caring for a child with that sort of disability is an expensive process-in case nobody in this chamber has ever noticed it. I would have thought that if the Government were going to take that line of argument anyway, it would at least be consistent about it. If people can afford a private plane, I am quite sure that they can afford the sales tax that was applying but which, under this legislation, will no longer apply. The Minister says that the sales tax is coming off private planes because it is too complicated to administer. He then tells us that it cannot come off computers and other equipment that have been adapted for people with disabilities because it is too difficult to administer. Please, could we stop watching Jim Hacker operating in Yes, Minister and get around to a little consistency, if not a little compassion. I am rather surprised that after all the years that we have been bringing this up in this place at least the Opposition is not prepared to support this proposal and see some merit in it. It is not too complicated to take the sales tax off. We do it for other items.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposition that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) put a little while ago regarding administrative difficulties quite frankly is false and can be shown to be false, which I will proceed to do now. In the first schedule of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act there are several items which necessitate the certification of a handicap to be produced before exemption from sales tax on certain goods is allowed. In other words, the procedures-whether the people who happen to be advising the Minister in the chamber at the moment know it or not-happen to be there already. Item 123a, which is the first schedule, provides exemption for interactive and broadcast videotex systems, broadcast teletext decoding devices, and similar decoding devices of a kind used in or in connection with television receivers where the system or device is for use and not for sale by profoundly deaf persons or persons taken to be profoundly deaf. Exemption for this equipment is on a restricted basis and available only to persons to whom a certificate as to the extent of their hearing disability has been furnished. This is a clear case where the mechanisms are already in place within the department. That is why I said that my amendment was couched in terms of something that is already operating.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at another item, item 135a of the schedule, which has provisions which requires evidence of a handicap before sales tax exemptions are offered to the persons seeking them. Under this item motor vehicles, and parts thereof, for use in the transportation to and from the gainful employment of a person in respect of whom the Director-General of Social Services, or an officer appointed by him for the purpose, has certified that he has lost the use of one or both legs to such an extent that he is permanently unable to use public transport are also exempt. In other words, we go through these mechanisms to deal with these particular issues. There is no administrative difficulty. If there were the Government would be taking certain items out of the legislation before us today for the reason it has given in respect of sales tax on aeroplanes, that is, that it is administratively difficult. The Government did not do it. Therefore it is accepting the proposition that these mechanisms are administratively available. My amendment fits into that category. There is nothing different. It is exactly the same mechanism.

Item 42 (17) refers to wigs and hairpieces for people who are clinically bald, provided there is certification that the person has lost his or her hair due to sickness or disease. The items go on and on. It is utter bunkum to suggest that this is administratively difficult because if it were the Government, following its line in terms of taking things out which are administratively difficult, would have sought to remove them long ago. It has not sought to do so. It has left them in there and it knows why it has left them in there. There is a very good case for those particular exemptions to be in the Act.

I reiterate a point that Senator Haines made about the dry economics that the Minister put forward-that if someone can afford 80 per cent of an item he can afford the 100 per cent. That is not a proposition which can endear itself to anybody--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the opposite of what I said. I said that it does not address the question of those who cannot afford the 80 per cent.

—It certainly does not address the problem of the 80 per cent. The suggestion now is that the Government is opposing this because it does not help everybody. I admit that it does not help everybody. I have been talking about this for years and the Government has not come forward with any proposition which will help everybody. I am trying to suggest alleviating part of the burden on those people. That is all. All I am suggesting is that we should not be making money out of those people who have a disability. I do not think anybody else in the community wants to take money out of their pockets. I do not think the community wants that tax. The community may have wanted a tax on executive jets which it just lost, but it certainly does not want a tax on equipment used by disabled people.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister wants to debate that, I would be quite happy to go out to any group in Australia to see how many people he can get on his side. It stands to reason that people do not want us to put a tax on these items. We want to alleviate the burden somewhat, and that is all we are doing. I am not suggesting that this is the be all and end all, or somehow or other a magic panacea for those people. I have seen what goes on in those circumstances. I have had personal contact with such people. I know that this is only a very small amount of assistance to those people and their families, who suffer every day and who put in almost a 24-hour day. I know that it does not do everything. The Minister does not have to preach to me about that-I know full well. But it might assist people somewhat in acquiring the things that they need or that their children need to give them the best life they can have in our community.

I am suggesting that this is becoming more and more urgent because we are dealing with matters of a technological kind. More of those devices are coming onto the market. They have been developed and research has been done on them by multinationals. They are developed for a mass market, not for a specific market. I find it odd that provided a company will actually develop specific products at a very high cost-almost every product available to a disabled person is a very high cost product because of the very small group of people who will be using it-we will take the sales tax off but we will not do the same with lower cost products which are mass produced even though they are often incredibly effective. I have seen people suffering from quite severe cerebral palsy doing printing work. Sometimes it takes them hours to set up a page, but once they have set it up and got it out their enormous satisfaction is something that everybody should see. They can present to the world, in a way in which they have never been able to do before, a top class A1 product.

Many people in Australia are attempting to develop products and employment opportunities for disabled people. We need to give people those opportunities at a much younger age. We need to follow the philosophy that the Government put in its own Act regarding disabled people. We should allow disabled people to make the decisions-not some bureaucrat in the Australian Taxation Office-about which goods will or will not be of use to them.

My amendment is couched in that philosophy. While I may agree with the Minister on a number of items-we often find ourselves on the same side with regard to some of the things he says about medical practitioners-to bring that into this debate is a pretty poor argument. An argument about an industrial matter or one about pay is quite out of place with regard to the relationship between the patient and the medical practitioner or the occupational therapist. It has nothing to do with this particular item at all. The people working with disabled people are the people best qualified to suggest what is in their best interests. Whether at some other stage the Minister wants to debate whether they should be getting the type of remuneration they are getting is a totally different matter. I do not think that disabled people should be dragged into a brawl that the Minister may be having with the Australian Medical Association. Although at the end of the day I could very well end up agreeing with the Minister's attitude to the AMA, I do not agree that it has anything to do with this particular proposition.

I would urge honourable senators to look again at this. If they are unable to support it now could I at least ask that somebody look at this in more detail than has obviously happened to date. I cannot get anything out of the Department or anybody else. Yet on the other side in terms of the various groups who are working with disabled people they see this as the way ahead. They see this as a mechanism whereby they can get into a lot of the items that come on to the market. It may very well be-and I am indebted to Senator Hamer for making a suggestion on this and I hope he does not mind my saying that it was his suggestion-that it is possibly the kind of item that could be looked at by a Senate committee. I happen to think that if we are getting nowhere down this track perhaps we should do that.

Perhaps in these particular Acts we should not only look at this item but also look at all other items with regard to disabled people. The Acts must be riddled through with inconsistencies and they are certainly in no way commensurate with or in any way reflective of the philosophy that the Government has put in its own Act. I am merely I suppose expressing my exasperation with this particular exercise. It takes so long to address what I think is a relatively simple issue. I will accept the proposition that Senator Haines accepted. It might be tinkering at the edges. I am quite happy to tinker at the edges if that is all we are allowed to do because that tinkering to some of those families is mightily important, I can assure honourable senators. They have put it to me time and time again that it is important to them in their lifestyle and in the type of support that they are able to provide to their children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I want to pick up on a comment that was made by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), this time by way of interjection, on something that Senator Macklin said. Apparently the partially motivating force behind the Government's refusal to accept this and to see reason is that not everyone will benefit so the Government does not let anybody benefit. The Government believes that not everybody can afford to pay the 80 per cent and, therefore, it will not let those who can afford to pay the 80 per cent benefit from the fact that they do not have to pay the additional 20 per cent. If we are talking about fairness and equity and arguing that 100 per cent of people have to benefit from something or we do not do it, that if we offer a concession or a benefit or exemption or whatever and argue that unless 100 per cent of the people in the group can get some measure of assistance out of it we do not do it, then we will have to scrap most of the legislation that we deal with in this place. Why do we have group specific tax deductions, for example? Why do we have tax concessions that help some people even though they do not help everybody? Why do we allow tax concessions for rates, for example, when not everyone pays them? I have not heard the Minister argue that we should not offer certain tax concessions to companies which would allow some of them to get their tax payable down to zero cents in the dollar just because not everybody can get their tax payable down to zero cents in the dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: To argue that we cannot pass an amendment like this that will benefit people who are already behind a variety of eight balls, including an economic one, because not everyone will be able to take advantage of it is probably the weakest of the arguments that I have heard put before us. Any government operates on a system where items are means tested, where concessions are offered, where deductions are provided, where there may be benefits to some and not to others, where need is taken into account and, indeed, in far too many areas in the tax system where need does not even rate a mention. The more one has the better off one is quite frequently.

To argue that we cannot do this because not everyone will benefit, because not everybody will come up with the 80 per cent, is simply not on. I accept Senator Macklin's generous words about Senator Hamer for suggesting that maybe we refer this to a committee. But I for one, and I suspect families with children who have disabilities and indeed adults who have disabilities, are getting a bit tired of being committee reference material. We do not send off to committees the question of whether we can have negative gearing on foreign financed takeovers continued even though we know that is pushing up the foreign debt, even though we know it is depleting Consolidated Revenue because some companies can take advantage of it and some cannot.

Sending this matter to a committee means delaying a decision. There may be a decision and a useful decision at the end of it. But I ask the committee how many families and how many children will lose out while we sit around in this place and tinker around the margins in a committee debate? How many youngsters will miss out on the educational advantage of the sorts of items that Senator Macklin was talking about? How many families are going to watch their children not develop their potential because they cannot reach a keyboard? What is wrong with this place that we cheerfully accept the fact that Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd pays no tax on its $354m record profit because of the tax concessions that are available to it and yet we cavil at passing an amendment that is in keeping with the Government's own guidelines in this area and that provides a token amount-10 or 20 per cent-of offset to items that may mean the difference between a child developing sufficiently to operate as a complete, well-educated human being who may even get a job and become a taxpayer, and that child not doing that at all?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak very briefly on this because I was mentioned in reference to a suggestion I made to Senator Macklin. I should make it quite clear to Senator Haines that my purpose was not to delay any action in this area. My purpose was to try to achieve action in this area. I think it is a somewhat more complex problem than Senator Haines has recognised. I notice the Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee on Community Affairs already has a reference given to it two months ago on the subject of the employment of disabled persons. This might well be extended to deal with this sort of area, that is, how we can assist disabled people with assistance and equipment which will enable them to live as normal a life as possible. It is a complex area. Senator Walsh annoyed and antagonised Senator Haines by saying it. It is a question not merely of reducing sales tax. There may be other needs. This is probably an area where a Senate committee could perform very valuable work and would, as a result of its recommendations, command support of the whole Senate. I put it to the Australian Democrats in that light; not as a means of delaying but as a means of achieving something.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Bills agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that these Bills be reported without amendment.
—I rise only very briefly because I was quite prepared to move an amendment.
—You cannot move an amendment at this point if that is what you are seeking to do.

—I do not intend to move an amendment. I merely want to now speak to this question. I was hoping that we may have been able to work out some way to bring this matter to the attention of the Government in an incisive manner so as to ensure that we get a report to the Senate as quickly as possible for later debate. Nevertheless, I have discussed the matter with the Australian Democrats and they would be, I think, supportive of the kind of approach Senator Hamer has outlined; that is, some kind of investigation by a Senate committee. I can indicate that we in the Opposition would be very keen to see that that proceeds as quickly as possible. My only point therefore is to indicate that we give support to the general thrust of what Senator Macklin mentioned in his speech. We believe that the Government ought to examine this question as quickly as possible and in due course take it up with the Senate Committee on Community Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following upon what Senator Messner said, I think it would be important to have such a committee investigation, which would enable the officials from the Taxation Office to justify their silence on a number of these aspects. A number of years ago I had correspondence with departmental officials in respect of handicapped persons and their exemptions and so on, and I think it is important for them to be on notice that they will have to justify asserting that these quite reasonable suggestions should not be incorporated into legislation. That applies to various public servants across the board. The debate that has taken place in the committee stage has been useful and I am very hopeful that there is common ground now for ensuring that handicapped persons are able to live their lives in the completest fashion possible-very often that is far more complete than we are able to achieve in this Parliament-and that, as an assistance in that objective, we do not burden those persons with the taxes that we now burden them with.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a third time.
Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in the day the Senate requested that we report progress to enable the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to consult with his advisers and to inform the Committee as to how the Government was going to interpret the States Grants (General Revenue) Bill. It was pointed out that there were not only inconsistencies in the Bill, there were also defective and deficient definitions. Perhaps before I proceed further I might give the Minister the opportunity of giving us the benefit of the advice he has now received from his advisers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I do not concede that the Bill was defective but I did concede earlier that I was somewhat confused, as were Senator Watson and one or two others. I have obtained a more adequate explanation. I can read it into the record or seek leave to incorporate it. Senator Watson at least and I think one or two others who are interested in this have already been given a copy.
—I think it should be read; not everybody has a copy.

—The purpose of clause 7 of the Bill, which is the clause under discussion, is to provide a means by which the global borrowing limit that was agreed at the Premiers Conference by all States except Queensland can be enforced. Those limits are set out in subclause 7 (2), together with the limit proposed by the Commonwealth for Queensland. Borrowings are defined as having the same meaning as in the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Collection Act, which answers one of the specific queries Senator Watson had this morning. This Act defines borrowings in the same way as the global approach resolution of Loan Council to include both conventional borrowings and other means of raising money, such as leases and deferred payment schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: I expect that Senator Watson and others probably will recall that some years ago a number of States were devising means by which they could effectively get around the global limits that had been agreed, or the predecessors to the global limits. The term `borrowings' in that Act relates to borrowings otherwise than from the Commonwealth. Hence, as I have stated before, it does not cover the general purpose capital payments to the States which are provided as an outlay in the Commonwealth Budget in the form of loans to the States that are repayable. The borrowings covered by the Bill include any borrowings by a State, its semi-government and local authorities, government-owned companies and trusts. This includes borrowings by or on behalf of State financial institutions. However, the Commonwealth's legal advice is that in forming an opinion as to whether a State has exceeded its global borrowing limit the Treasurer would be bound to act in a way consistent with the arrangements agreed with the States and, in particular, the global approach resolution, which would clearly exclude any borrowings from the Commonwealth or by State financial institutions. The Government has assured the States in writing that the clause would be interpreted in that way.

A broad definition of the bodies whose borrowings were subject to the clause was included because there is no straightforward difference in legal structure between the financial institutions and other State authorities; because the global approach relies on informal agreement between the Commonwealth and the States, based on the definitions used for statistical purposes as to what constitutes a financial institution; and finally because some authorities combine the functions of financial institutions with other functions in the same legal structure.

So, in summary, the clause is worded as it is essentially for technical reasons, but for those who fear that the intention of the clause may be exceeded because of the way it is worded, that fear is addressed by the guarantee given in writing by the Commonwealth to the States that that will not be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume from the Minister's answer that he does not propose to make changes to the legislation but proposes to issue a letter from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to the States as to how he intends to interpret inadequate and inefficient legislation. I put it to the Minister that there is no place for a Treasurer to issue a statement of intent as to how he is going to interpret legislation which is clearly deficient and defective and when amendments to the Act are required. I put it to the Minister: if after hearing my reasoned proposition to him that there is scope for tightening up the provisions of the Bill, which must include a clarification-simple words, simple amendments-perhaps we might have to report progress until next Monday to enable the Committee to remedy defective legislation and to improve something that is essentially a highly contentious area.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge that there has been a problem. Unanimous agreement for the global resolution was not achieved because Queensland walked out as a result of the high-handed treatment it received from the Treasurer at the May Premiers Conference. If it be a lesson to anybody, surely it should be a lesson to the Treasurer that the States must be taken note of and their concerns acknowledged in some way, and that one should not ride roughshod over the Premiers. To get agreement, I understand-and I stand to be corrected-that unanimous agreement is required. In the circumstances Treasurer Keating was unable to get unanimous agreement as the Queensland representatives walked out because of the way they had been treated.

The present Bill does not relate to borrowings otherwise than from the Commonwealth. Those words specifically need to be included to tighten up this area. After all, we are dealing with often contentious negotiations between the Commonwealth and the States. Misunderstandings occur and there has been a failure, as I pointed out in my speech of the second reading, by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to honour previous commitments and undertakings. It is inadequate to adopt a procedure requiring the Treasurer to issue guidelines as to how he will interpret legislation. The function of the Senate is to ensure that we get the legislation right rather than relying on a letter from the Treasurer as to how he will interpret the words `global resolution'.

I put it to the Minister that there is scope in three areas to tighten this legislation. We will be satisfied if the Minister undertakes to come back with a tighter resolution. Otherwise I am afraid that we shall have to report progress to give the Minister until next Monday to get the legislation right by including some simple words to put the matter beyond reasonable doubt. The Minister acknowledges that there is doubt since he has said that there will be an undertaking by the Treasurer, or indeed he may have already given it in a letter to the States. We acknowledge a need to pay general revenue grants. I think they are paid weekly or fairly regularly. We do not intend to hold up these payments, which are very necessary to the States, but we are giving the Minister a reasonable time to put his house in order.

It might be said that this is annual legislation and it is unlikely that there will be difficulty or infringement enabling the States or instrumentalities to exceed the global limits. In that case the matter will not come up before next year and there will be new legislation on the books. But perhaps the Minister's successor next year will say, `We will rely on this legislation as it was good enough last year' and it may not be corrected next year. Certainly the present position is not good enough. The Minister has the facility to bring forward appropriate amendments in a statute law revision Bill, but certainly a global resolution requires unanimous agreement, as the Minister must acknowledge. There was confusion last night when the Minister said that the definition of `State instrumentality' according to the Attorney-General's Department did not include State banks and State institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I misunderstood you.

—This morning we were advised by the Treasury that it did. I ask for clarification as to how the conflict between the two is to be resolved. I am advised that the legal argument referred not to the definition, as the Minister implied last night in respect of State instrumentalities, but to how the Treasurer's discretionary powers could be interpreted. I think that the Senate is entitled to know that.

SPEECH.PARA: A further point arises on this Bill. If we accept the Treasury's advice in terms of the definition of State instrumentality as to whether it includes State banks, if it does so-and I believe it does and the Treasury advice says it does, although the Minister says that the Attorney-General's opinion says it does not-and if we are to proceed on that basis, surely it will subvert the intention of the Loan Council. That is unsatisfactory and only legal change of the definition will overcome the problem.

The Minister's definition of `new borrowings' creates a problem as it remains unclear how the loan component of the general purpose capital assistance has been precluded from being classified as a new borrowing. A simple amendment is required to include the words `otherwise than from the Commonwealth'. It is technical but it is necessary. If the Minister is trying to push through sloppy legislation, it is up to the Opposition, including the Australian Democrats, to make sure the Minister gets it right, that he dots the i's and crosses the t's. After all, we are still in a federation. We are dealing with States, with regular payments and revenue grants from the Commonwealth to the States. It is a contentious area and must be got right. Is the Minister prepared to change the legislation, or does he intend to push it through and rely on a discretionary letter of intent as to how the Treasury will apply defective and inadequate definitions for the purpose of reimbursing the States? How does the Minister intend to proceed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the point on which my colleague Senator Watson concluded, I trust that there is no intention by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) or the Government to push this legislation through this evening in its current unsatisfactory state. There would be no excuse or basis for any such action other than the discomfort which the Government is currently feeling as a result of the fact that it has placed before the Parliament, and pushed through the House of Representatives, legislation which, on examination in this place, proves to be technically defective. It would be a gross abuse of what the Government no doubt would call the application of numbers if it were simply to use its numbers-and I presume that it would hope to obtain the numbers of the Australian Democrats-to achieve that purpose. I do not accuse the Government of that intention, but in view of Senator Watson's concluding remarks I thought I should begin by addressing myself to that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of another comment made by Senator Watson, I would point out that in case the Government is thinking of arguing that it is necessary to get this legislation through because it is necessary to make these arrangements as soon as possible and not hold up the payment of these general revenue grants to States, then as the Minister is well aware, there is full power under the legislation in the preceding Act of 1985 to continue to make advance payments for the succeeding year, that is to say, the year we are now in. That is as I understand the position, and if I am wrong no doubt the Minister will correct me. There is certainly a comparable provision in the legislation for this year in respect of 1989-90.

I come to the clause of the Bill which is causing the problem. It is a clause to which I referred at some length in my speech yesterday evening in the second reading debate when, as Senator Watson said, the Minister gave some responses both to Senator Watson's remarks and to mine-responses which he now concedes were based on a misunderstanding of what we had been referring to. I accept that the Minister's responses were given in good faith at the time and I make no further criticism in that regard other than to say that the record will now show that the responses given at the time were in error.

I direct the attention of honourable senators to the extraordinary situation that now exists. Last May the Commonwealth met in Loan Council with the Premiers and Treasurers of all six States and the Northern Territory. A resolution was reached with five of those States to govern the so-called global borrowing limits for 1988-89. The Queensland Government did not agree with that resolution and has continued to differ with the Commonwealth on it. As a consequence, this punitive clause of the Bill, clause 7, seeks to give power to the Treasurer to impose a penalty upon any State which, in the opinion of the Treasurer, at the unfettered discretion of the Treasurer, exceeds the global borrowing limit imposed upon that State-and, indeed, all States-by the Commonwealth last May. Be that as it may, the imposition at that time of those global borrowing limits was in the framework of a resolution of the Loan Council-I have forgotten what the precise title of the resolution was-governing the global borrowing limits of the States. In terms of that resolution there are certain definitions as to what is and what is not covered by those global borrowing limits; in other words, by the term `borrowings' for that purpose. Yet the Bill contains a different definition. That is the nub of the Government's problem.

The Minister has been good enough during the day-and I acknowledge his courtesy-to circulate to me, Senator Watson, and possibly other senators, some points which he read into the record this evening which seek to bridge this gap between the two quite diverse definitions-on the one hand, the global borrowing limits resolution of the Loan Council and, on the other, the definition of what constitutes borrowings in clause 7 (1) (a) of the Bill. I will not go over the ground again because it has been covered by both Senator Watson and me, last night and again, to some degree, a little earlier by Senator Watson. Let me raise a few points for consideration by the Minister and honourable senators as to the effects of passing this legislation in its current form. I imagine that the Minister will urge that we do so.

Let us consider first the example that I touched on briefly last night: a borrowing by the State Bank of Victoria. There is no doubt that such a borrowing constitutes a borrowing by an instrumentality of the Government of Victoria and is therefore covered by the definition in clause 7 (1) (a) of the Bill. Such a borrowing, however, would not be a borrowing for the purposes of the Loan Council resolution governing the global limits. It is not included within that coverage for the purpose of that resolution. What we have been told today by the Minister-it was read into the record a moment ago-is that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has made it plain in correspondence with the State governments that, notwithstanding what might be contained in the Bill, borrowings of that kind would not be counted as borrowings for the purposes of penalty clause 7 (1) (b).

On the face of it that, in itself, is a sufficiently strange situation to warrant considerable comment, but that is not the entire point that I want to make. In that case the State of Victoria, by having one of its instrumentalities make such a borrowing, would actually exceed the borrowings shown in the table in clause 7 (2) beside the name `Victoria', but it would not be subject to a penalty for doing so. It would endure no penalty, even though, clearly, it would be in breach of the provisions of clause 7 (1).

Let me turn to the other example, involving the Government of Queensland. I remind the Committee that this whole apparatus is directed towards that Government. Queensland does not have a State bank, so let us assume that one of its financial intermediaries, Suncorp-which, for the benefit of non-Queensland senators, is the equivalent of the State Government Insurance Corporation in most other States-borrows in the financial markets and uses the proceeds to buy a parcel of mortgages from the State Government Housing Commission. The State Government Housing Commission is perfectly entitled to sell its assets. That does not constitute a borrowing on the part of the State Government Housing Commission, although it does involve a borrowing by Suncorp. With the proceeds of that sale of assets the Housing Commission can then proceed to build some more houses, thereby undertaking the kind of economic activity which I presume the Government has set out to stop it undertaking.

It would be open to the Treasurer, in terms of this Bill, to say that Suncorp, as a Government instrumentality of the State of Queensland, has made a borrowing-there would not be any doubt that that was so-and that because it had made a borrowing he proposed to implement the punitive measures open to him and entirely at his unfettered discretion under clause 7 (1) (b) of the Bill. Of course, if he were to do so, he would be operating totally differently from the manner in which he operated, by turning a blind eye, in the case of the Victorian example. Both of these hypothetical borrowings-on the one hand by the State Bank of Victoria and on the other by the Suncorp instrumentality of Queensland-constitute borrowings by financial intermediaries. There is no difference between them in that sense. The only difference so far as I can see is that one is made by a government which the Treasurer does not want to punish and the other is made by a government which he does want to punish, for purely political reasons.

The point on which I focus, leaving aside the political question, is that this would involve totally discriminatory treatment between the two States-treatment that is entirely out of accord with the text of the legislation. This piece of legislation is supposed to apply-indeed, for good constitutional reasons, it must apply-without any discriminatory basis between the States. It must apply equally between the States. Yet the only way in which the Treasurer in those circumstances can make his writ run, to impose the penalty which he is hell-bent on imposing on Queensland-otherwise we would not have clause 7 in the Bill; that is the only reason that it appears-is to discriminate between the two States in his treatment of a borrowing by two financial intermediaries in the two cases.

Such a situation would be quite extraordinary. It would take the actions initiated at the May meeting of the Loan Council to a further depth of iniquity on the part of the Treasurer of the Commonwealth. I trust that that will not be the case. This situation is intolerable. The piece of legislation has been drafted in such a way that it states one thing, but we are told by the Minister that the Treasurer has already given certain assurances to the States by letter that it will not be interpreted in terms of the plain meaning of the language of the law.
