DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 August, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill makes a number of major changes to the export market development grants (EMDG) system and it makes those changes pursuant to the May statement, when the Government announced that it would make a number of pre-Budget changes, some of which involve reductions of expenditure. It is well known in the Senate that since the time of the previous Budget, that is, the Budget brought down in August 1987, the Opposition had said that it would be necessary for the Government to have a mini-Budget, and indeed we called for one in the Senate very shortly after the Budget that was brought down in 1987. It took the Government some time to come to the conclusion that that was necessary. We had a May statement which announced a number of significant economic changes during that Budget year.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the export market development grants changes, many exporters were somewhat surprised by the changes because the Government had made very clear statements during the election campaign that it intended to maintain the program. Indeed, the Government was highly critical of the Opposition for suggesting changes to the grants scheme, even suggesting the abolition of the scheme, accompanied by very substantial tax changes. In any event, after severely criticising the Opposition and making all sorts of undertakings to exporters, the Government found itself able to change its mind and to announce the changes that are to be made by this Bill.

The major changes are as follows: The Bill will raise the threshold for eligible expenditure from $5,000 a year to $10,000 a year. This change is likely to affect smaller businesses, the people who are at the beginnings of export and who may have relatively small amounts of expenditure. The Opposition has never opposed the idea of there being some cut-off point because, obviously, administratively that is very sensible; but this change raises the threshold for eligible expenditure from $5,000 to $10,000 a year. In addition, the maximum annual grant payable to exporters who have received eight grants will be reduced to $150,000, and to $100,000 for those who are in receipt of a tenth or subsequent grant. This will wean comparatively successful importers off the scheme. Maximum grants to exporters after two years will also be reduced.

The Bill makes changes to the treatment of affiliated companies so that they are treated as one unit in the assessment of export grants. That is to reduce the capacity of any related businesses to get grants not subject to those various cut-offs. The change will prevent the restructuring of companies merely to increase access to grants. Finally, because of the development of the single market between New Zealand and Australia under the closer economic relations agreement, the Government has proposed that Australian exporters should not receive assistance in developing New Zealand markets. The Bill provides that export promotion expenditure in New Zealand will no longer be eligible.

The Opposition does not propose to oppose this legislation. In the main, we have taken the stance that where the Government moves to reduce expenditure-we have been saying virtually throughout the whole of the life of this Government that it has been spending more than Australian taxpayers can afford, that it has been adding to our debt too much and keeping taxes too high-we will not oppose legislation which reduces government expenditure, even though the changes made may not be changes which we, in government, would make. In other words, we have not sought the capacity to remake the Government's Budget here in the Senate or in the House of Representatives. That commitment, which is very convenient and helpful to the Government, is entirely appropriate, given the economic difficulties that Australia has faced and the difficulties that the Government would face in economic management if there were a substantial remaking of the Budget in dealing with this sort of legislation. So, for that reason, whilst we are highly critical of what the Government is doing, we do not propose to amend this legislation or to vote against it.

Another thing which needs to be said is that the Opposition, as part of its approach at the last general election, proposed to do away with the export market development grants as part of its own process of expenditure reduction. We took the view that it was far better to significantly reduce government expenditure across the board and to very significantly reduce the tax burden at the same time than to have the churning effect of collecting higher taxes from businesses and individuals and returning those same taxes to them as benefits, with the accompanying losses that are occasioned by the process of both collecting and disbursing the money.

I remind the Senate that the context of our promise to remove this form of assistance to exporters was that contemporaneously we were proposing to introduce very significant cuts to the company tax rate, initially from 49c in the dollar to 42c, from 1 July 1988, with the intention of getting it down to 38c in the dollar. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will remember the cries of `Irresponsibility!' that were levelled at the Opposition when we suggested that, although since that time the present Government-I often wonder, Mr Acting Deputy President, how honourable senators like you feel about this-from 1 July 1988 reduced the company tax rate to 39c in the dollar. So, what in the election campaign had been called an act of economic vandalism became something that the Government did itself.

The Government has financed the reduction in the taxes which are paid by business by increasing the effective tax rates on individual wage and salary earners. So your constituents, Mr Acting Deputy President, are paying an ever higher proportion of their incomes-often meagre incomes-in taxation. That is why they are feeling such a squeeze in their standard of living. That is why they see this Government as being arrogant and out of touch. It can deliver a 10c reduction in the company tax rate from 1 July, but it can say to the wage and salary earners of Australia, `You will have to wait for your tax cuts until just before the next Federal election'. That is the sort of reason why the voters in so many seats which have been such safe Labor seats have chosen to vote for the Liberal Party or the National Party in preference to their traditional allegiance.

One of the offers that were contemporaneously made to exporters by the Opposition was a reduction of the company tax rate. That reduction was not to be accompanied, as this Government has done, by the removal of the very favourable depreciation provisions which business enjoys and which will recoup some of the tax reduction which has been given to them by this Government. It was also part of the Opposition's tax policy to abolish the capital gains tax; to abolish the fringe benefits tax in its entirety, subject only to provisions which would prevent abuse of that; to restore reductions for legitimate business expenses incurred in earning assessable income; and so on. So a very generous package of tax reductions was proposed by the Opposition which would have delivered very considerable benefits to business at the time the export market development grants were being removed.

We faced at the time a very strong campaign by the Government which sought the votes of exporters by making the point that it certainly was not going to interfere with the export market development grants program. All sorts of statements were made by Government spokesmen prior to the last election, expressing alarm at what the Liberal Party was proposing. For example, the Minister for Trade at the time, Mr Dawkins, chose to write to many businesses on Government letterhead-I do not know who paid for it; perhaps the Labor Party paid for it, but it was obviously a blatantly political letter-expressing his alarm at the Liberal Party's plans for the EMDG and expressly quoting the Liberals' tax policy. That is fine. Mr Dawkins said, `Boosting our exports is vital and scrapping government help for exporters is folly'.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) bought into this argument. He gave an assurance that funding for Austrade and the export market development grants scheme would remain intact if the Labor Government were re-elected. The Prime Minister, in his Australian Financial Review luncheon speech in Brisbane on 16 June 1987, attacked what he described as a `visionless statement by the Liberals' to reduce export assistance and quoted the Confederation of Australian Industry. He said, `What Australia desperately needs now is more exports. The export market development grants scheme will give these exporters a vital helping hand, and that is why the third Hawke Government will retain them'.

It is important, in trying to understand the scope of the government's commitment to exporters, to refer to a further statement by Mr Dawkins-as I said, the then Minister for Trade-who, in a media release headed `Dawkins Reassures Industry on Hawke Government Support for Export Drive', said on 22 June 1987:
I have also assured them-
meaning exporters-
that we will not undermine their effort by chipping away at the spearhead of Australia's export drive-Austrade.
In that statement we have a commitment to the continuation of the export market development grants scheme. It is in that context that I move the following second reading amendment:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(a) the Government has misled exporters;
(b) the amendments in this Bill constitute fundamental changes to the Export Market Development Grants Scheme; and

(c) as such, they are a breach of the undertakings given by the Prime Minister and the then Minister for Trade during the 1987 election campaign, that the scheme would be allowed to run its full course''.

On this issue, the Labor Party then campaigned in a way which was designed to make it quite clear to exporters that they could rely upon the maintenance of this program. In the May statement, just 10 or 11 months after those statements of the Prime Minister and Mr Dawkins to which I have referred, they found that the Government was not going to keep that promise after all. I think that is typical of the hypocrisy that has been displayed by this Government and its contempt for the electorate. Again, it is the sort of behaviour which has led to the strong electoral backlash which has been experienced by the Government over the last 12 months. Just as the Prime Minister promised that there would be no capital gains tax and later he brought one in, he promised that there would be no whittling away of the scheme and, of course, that is precisely what this legislation is now doing.

Can it be said that the need for government assistance with respect to exports has come to an end? Is it a fact that the export crisis is over? In 1986 Mr Keating told us that Australia was headed towards the status of a banana republic; and that was because we had this booming growth of our imports and our exports were not keeping up, we had a great trade gap, and our dollar was plunging as a result. Of course, since that time the Government has gained some advantage and Australia has gained some advantage from the change in the terms of trade. Through 1986 we heard nothing from Government Ministers other than that the difficulties Australia faced were difficulties which were caused by the fact that our terms of trade had declined-in other words, people buying our goods overseas were not prepared to pay as much for them as they had paid the year before, and this was giving rise to our great difficulties-ignoring the fact that that has been a continuing difficulty throughout our history. Indeed, since 1951, if we look at that period of very high export prices, we see a graph where there are many dips in our terms of trade. Mr Keating was complaining at one stage of a 9.8 per cent loss in our terms of trade in one year, forgetting that there had been a loss of a very similar magnitude in 1978 during the period of the Fraser Government. I do not remember Mr Keating or the Labor Party regarding that as anything other than an excuse at that time.

But the really significant point is that the terms of trade have improved since 1986. They have turned down a bit since the middle of this year and that is a worry for Australia as we know that our commodities are essentially very volatile, but we have had a year and a half of good prices. There has been some slackening off since June but we have still had comparatively good prices. In fact, the loss of the value of our exports that Mr Keating was complaining about has been made up. But when we actually look at what is happening in terms of physical trade in goods and services, we see that the position has worsened since 1986. The tragedy is that the period of ease, the period of relief which has been given to Australia by the improvement in the prices which have been paid for our major commodities has been utterly wasted by this Government, because whilst in real terms we have had a growth in the exports of goods and services, we have had an even larger growth in our imports. So in terms of the physical trade in goods and services things are not getting better; they are getting worse. Of course, that means that the export crisis is greater today than it was in 1986. When we look at the physical goods and services we see that any reversal of our terms of trade today will be a far more serious matter because the actual gap between what we sell abroad and what we buy from abroad has widened.

In real terms exports grew by 5.8 per cent in 1985-86, by 8 1/2 per cent in 1986-87 and by 5.8 per cent last year, with the budget predicting a growth this year of about 6 per cent. Real import growth has been strong, especially last year, with a 9.1 per cent growth, and the Budget forecasts an increase of 9 1/2 per cent this financial year. So in the last financial year we have had a growth of 5.8 per cent in what we sell abroad-that is, in physical terms-and imports go up by 9.1 per cent. There is a 6 per cent increase in what we are likely to sell abroad this year, with the Government predicting a 9 1/2 per cent increase in our imports. So if we combine the two, exports minus imports, the net export growth was negative and the contribution of net exports to gross domestic product (GDP) growth was minus 0.5 per cent in 1987-88. In other words, the net export position made a negative contribution to our GDP and the Budget forecast for 1988-89 is the same. We will have another reduction of half of one per cent in our GDP because of that gap.

Whilst in nominal terms-that is, in terms of present value money-the trade balance on goods and services has improved, falling from a deficit of $7 1/2 billion in 1985-86 to a deficit of $3 billion in 1987-88, if the value of the terms of trade improvement is added to this latter figure, the nominal deficit is around $6 billion. Without the pick-up in commodity prices there has been little improvement on the goods and services trade account as confirmed by the net export figures.

The relevance of all that to this legislation is that this Government is reducing assistance to exporters without providing accompanying tax relief, which, of course, is the proposition that we were providing, without many of the measures that we were putting forward at the same time, in breach of its clear undertakings to exporters; and the country is facing continuing difficulties. There are a number of difficulties for exporters in what is proposed. Take, for example, the removal of assistance to people who are exporting to New Zealand. I have had direct representations from constituents on this. The truth is that if people were relying upon what the Government had said and decided that they were going to open up their export trade to New Zealand and they were prepared to budget-as certainly one constituent who came in and showed me the figures was; the figures showed that a market in foodstuffs could be opened up in New Zealand and, provided the grants were paid, the whole thing looked like a reasonable economic proposition-and they set down that course and went down that track, they would wake up on the morning after the May statement and would find that their budget had been invalidated.

This legislation is not retrospective in a technical sense but it certainly alters the basis on which people were carrying out their commercial planning when they were expanding exports relying on the promises of Mr Hawke and Mr Dawkins. At the moment there are some very sour exporters in Australia who did rely-I do not know why they did, given Mr Hawke's record on breaking promises-on the undertakings of Mr Hawke and Mr Dawkins and who now find that their budgets have been invalidated and that the basis on which they went into exports will certainly not be as good for them as it would have been had the Government not made these changes.

So our concern about this legislation is that it is typical of the mishmash, episodic way that this Government goes about so much of its legislation that impacts upon business activity. It is not only in this field of exports. Look at the absolute plight of so many people in the motor industry over the last three years-an industry which, over the last 12 months, has happily seen a lift in sales. Look at the pain which has been imposed on many of the people in that industry by the fact that, on the one hand, the Government has produced a motor plan which has opened up the industry to greater competition and which is aiming to provide cheaper vehicles for Australian people and, on the other hand, the Government has turned round and imposed increases in sales tax, changes to the arrangements with respect to the fringe benefits tax and so on and an interest rates policy which is absolutely punishing, which has contributed to the smashing down of the market for motor vehicles over several years. It is that lack of consistency, that lack of a framework which overall can be relied upon, which is at the heart of our criticism of this legislation. This is a Government which in our view has maintained unconscionably high taxes. It has, over the course of its life, been unconscionably high spending. It is not the role of the Opposition in our view to force up government expenditure in this country. For that reason, as I said earlier, we will not be voting against this legislation, but I believe that the Senate should record as its view that the Government has misled exporters, that it has fundamentally changed the export market development grants scheme, and that it has breached the undertakings of both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill 1988. I do this bearing in mind the increasing importance and necessity of Australia and its position in export trade. I need to start at the beginning because export potential is totally tied to the country's overall economic position. The discussion has to proceed on the basis and in the light of our current overseas balances, our interest rate, our taxation policies, our currency values, our employment levels, the seasonal conditions, our industrial relations, and so on. All those things have a bearing.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to pick out only one of those at this stage. Two reports have been produced this year, one by the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) and one by Price Waterhouse. Instructions were given in January 1988 for these two organisations to complete their reports. There has been a considerable change in the economic situation since then. There has been a considerable change in the value of the currency since then. There is a lot of difference in how we view the world and how the world views us. It makes a lot of difference, for instance, whether our dollar is worth US65 cents or US70 cents or whether it is pumped up to 82 cents, as it is now. Even the changes that have occurred since January this year would make a lot of difference to anybody seeking to be in the export market. We also need to consider initially the import question. Senator Chaney, my leader, spoke on this matter. I have today's figures from the Daily Commercial News. The news article states:
Imports increased by $192m to $3,825m from $3,632m in July and $3,232m in June.
In the first two months of the 1988-89 financial year, the value of imports increased by 15.8% to $7,457m from $6,439m in July and August last year.
For the three months ended August 1988 imports increased by 11.0% on the same period of last year, which was nearly double the rise of 5.9% recorded for exports.

How long can we go on with a rise in imports or a rise that is twice as steep as the rise in exports? Can we continue on this basis? How can we ignore the value of the American dollar at the same time? That seems to be the currency by which we are gauged around the world. If we continue up this road how close are we to going out backwards and hanging the sign on the door saying that we have gone? We must build our exports and we must produce new exporters, and lots of them. I ask the Government: Will this Bill do that? Is it what is required to be done? Were the people who did these reviews instructed to move in and see by how much they could cut the money?

Let us look at the indicators from the history of the scheme. In the review of the Bureau of Industry Economics table 2.1 demonstrates that in 1978-79 there were 3,918 claimants. In 1986-87 there were 3,530 claimants, actually less than in the first year I mentioned. That was, of course, after we had been through years like 1982-83 when there were 6,535 claimants and 1983-84 when there were 6,387 claimants. Those were years when we were trying to build up exports. Now we are on the slippery slide and going down rapidly. The number of people who are eligible to claim under this new scheme is also going down rapidly. This is before the latest reductions. All we know is that the scheme is due to be wound up on 30 June 1990. It looks as though we will try to wind it up before then. The circumstances have changed since the Government decided to take this action.

It is interesting to note that table 2.3 on page 8 of the same publication demonstrates that of the 3,530 claimants, 2,007 were in manufacturing, 745 were in wholesale and retail, and 286 were in finance, property and business services. It also shows that of the groups which carry the Australian export market, agriculture had 97 claimants and mining had 52. Although those sectors produce in the order of 80 per cent of exports the numbers of claimants is very small. Over the period I have mentioned the average claim has risen from $15,300 to $50,500. Who is exporting?

We need to have a fresh look at the whole system. If we are to increase our export effort we have to have new exporters, new markets and new products. Those questions were identified by the two groups that did the investigation. Both commented on the same points. I will read from a couple of areas of the publication by the Bureau of Industry Economics. On page 18 it referred to new exporters in these terms:

If the measure of the extent of assistance provided to new exporters is taken to be the number of claimants who have received less than three grants, then this objective has been met quite well. More than 40 per cent of the claimants in 1986-87 fall into this category.
An additional indicator is that some 2,500 firms have been encouraged into attempting export market development through the Scheme in the last nine years.
It then goes on to talk about new markets on page 19. It states:

The data suggests that, on average, more new markets are entered by firms in their early years in the Scheme than in later years. Average new markets appear to be greater for firms in their first year, as would be expected, but from the second year to the eighth year, an average of one new market per year per claimant appears to be being developed. After the eighth year new market development, on average, declines markedly.
It then goes on about new products. It states:

Encouragement of new products is not achieved very well by the Scheme. The data suggest that development of new products appears, on average, to be minimal after claimants have been in the Scheme longer than one year.
It shows that the scheme, whatever its intentions, is not working to get to the people we are really after. I am sure that the changes we are proposing will not bring in a new group of exporters.
The conclusions, also on page 19 of that report, briefly are:
In particular, assistance has been provided to:
established exporters who were not developing new markets . . .
exporters to areas such as New Zealand which are little different to Australia for the purposes of market development; and
exporters who are not as committed as is necessary for success in exporting.

It is rather unfortunate that we seem to have reached the position where we are paying many of the people who, according to these reports, did not need the money or were not using it wisely. But back to exports. The aims of any export stimulation scheme very clearly have to be to encourage industry to export; to achieve export income; to expand Australia's productivity; to extend the skills of Australians; and to improve the living standards of all Australians. Looking at the same list of desirable objectives of the BIE report, it summarises them quite well. I again quote those:
. . . objectives which the EMDG Scheme should possess can be developed. These are that:
The Scheme should concentrate on new exporters and on small to medium-sized firms;
firms should spend a significant amount of their own funds on market development;
an export performance test should be applied that provides an incentive for the firm to export after a reasonable time spent in market development;
assistance should be given for the development of markets in countries about which potential exporters have the greatest difficulty estimating the costs and benefits of export market development;
firms should be required to provide an export plan;
the external benefits generated by exporters should be readily available to potential exporters;
the Scheme should be administratively efficient for both claimants and the Government;
the Scheme should complement other AUSTRADE and Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce Industry Programs; and
enough information should be collected from those using and administering this Scheme that its effectiveness can be readily measured.

That is good. These guidelines are most reasonable. How do we achieve them? To achieve what we are trying to do must lie basically with new exports, because once in, the problems are somewhat less. The encouragement of new exports is vital. Most of all, continuity is absolutely essential. Knowing what the Government will do is absolutely fundamental. Of course, we do know what the Government will do because it has told us over and over again.

Senator Chaney made mention of what Mr Dawkins said that the Government would do. I do not wish to repeat all of the excellent material that Mr Dawkins has provided us with. He did say that scrapping Government help for exporters is folly. I completely agree, particularly when one has promised them one will not-it is folly. Then, of course, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) saw fit to quote Mr Daryl George, the Chief Executive of the Confederation of Australian Industry, when he said:
Stability and certainty in the formation and implementation of industry policies are crucial.

The Prime Minister said, `Good old Mr George, we support you totally'. But did he support him totally? Of course he did not. Before the ink was dry he said, `Oh no, the election is over. We've won that. We don't have to run for the train once we've caught it. We'll see what we can do to rip the rug out from under these exporters. If we play our cards right we can save $52m'. That is what the whole program has been about. So much for that.

To get new exporters requires, of course, the best market information that one can provide. It requires researching of the niches and the opportunities all over the world. It requires appropriate credit and insurance facilities. These have to be easily operated. It requires the availability of literature, staff, seminars, et cetera to aid the decision making and to reduce the high initial costs and risk that are associated with going into something that is unknown, and the meeting of costs adequately through tax issues and other means. The package that we in Opposition and in coalition put out at that time covered all of those things. What has the Government done? I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Divorce Law-Overseas Students Program: Permanent Resident Status

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being nearly 7.30 p.m. I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Normally I do not rise on the adjournment but I ask the indulgence of you, Mr President, and the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). I will be raising a couple of topics but I will be as brief as I can. They are two quite different cases. One involves a woman who, after being left a widow, remarried in 1964. The couple went to live on her property. In 1977 she was diagnosed as having a brain tumour and her condition was regarded as terminal. While under treatment in hospital and heavily sedated at the time, she signed over to her husband the property and her other funds so that he could administer them. She was not, I remind the Minister, expected to survive this operation. However, in some ways perhaps unfortunately, she did. Senator Patterson is laughing but she will find out why I suspect this woman would have preferred not to have lived given the problems that occurred thereafter.

SPEECH.PARA: She arranged to return home to convalesce. When she did her husband told her that he did not want her to come back to the property which now belonged to him and that furthermore he had, `another woman in her bed'. There was not a great deal that she could do apparently. She was sent some money by her only daughter and son-in-law to go and recuperate with them overseas, ultimately in the United Kingdom. Some months later in 1978 she returned to Adelaide to find that her husband had divorced her and claimed ownership of all her property. She then went on a pension. In addition, she took presumably part time casual postings as a teacher in a local high school and filled out the rest of her time with some voluntary work.

Friends of hers, who were somewhat angry at her husband's behaviour and use of her property, persuaded her to take action to repossess that property or at least get half its value, with the help of legal aid. With the help of the Legal Services Commission in South Australia, a law firm was eventually appointed to take up her case. As sometimes happens, it apparently did not seem too enthusiastic about it and after a couple of years passed the case on to an associate law firm, which a year later-by this time it is 1988-presented the case, allegedly incompletely, advising her to say nothing in court. Meantime her husband, who was quite significantly wealthy, managed to get the services of a barrister who put his case well, arguing among other things that, as the case had not come up in court within a year of the divorce, it was not admissible. There being no apparent objection from the Legal Services people representing her, the judge dismissed the case.

The woman is now over 70, living in a little flat and making as much of her life as she can. Her friends have asked a series of questions which, if the above information is accurate, deserve some kind of answer. When she was in court, why did her legal adviser not stress that this appeal limit of a year was quite unrealistic under the circumstances? Why did her legal adviser not hold out for the usual fifty-fifty settlement in marital divisions, given-I remind the Senate-that she was divorced when she was out of the country and was not able to be present? Why was not any emphasis placed on the conditions under which she signed the original documents giving her husband jurisdiction to administer her property?

I would be grateful to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) if he could give some advice or recommend some way of solving the problem. I am personally at a loss to see how anybody can help this woman. Clearly an injustice has been perpetrated, and if the Minister knows of any way at all in which she can be helped, I am quite happy to give him the name and address of the woman concerned. I certainly do not want it to be put in the Hansard records.

The second case is a more general one. I guess it is one that a lot of other senators would have run into from time to time. It concerns a loophole in or a misuse of Australia's overseas students program and our immigration system. The particular case involves a young woman who arrived in Australia in 1984 with her husband and two children to enable her husband to commence postgraduate studies at an Australian university. Shortly after the family's arrival the husband became involved with another woman, an Australian citizen, whom he subsequently married following the couple's divorce in 1986. After his remarriage the man applied for and was granted permanent resident status in Australia.

He then withdrew from his course of study-the reason, I remind everybody, that he was granted permission to come into the country in the first place-and has, I have been told although I have not been able to verify this, left his second wife. His marriage to her, of course, enabled him to obtain permission to remain as a permanent resident, having got in here in the first place as a PhD student at an Australian university. In the meantime, of course, his former wife and their children automatically became prohibited non-citizens upon dissolution of the marriage and have been advised that they must leave the country. For some time the woman has been trying to gain permission for herself and her children to remain in Australia but, fairly obviously, to no avail.

The Government cannot be held responsible, obviously, for the breakdown of the marriage and the subsequent difficulties flowing from such an occurrence, but I think it can take some responsibility for, or at least it ought to be concerned about, a situation which allows individuals to work the system to their own advantage with such apparent ease. Marriage is the major ground by which overseas students apply for change of status under section 6a (1) (b) of the Migration Act and the majority of applications are granted. The process is very simple. The applicant fills in the relevant application form and presents his or her marriage certificate, along with four statutory declarations from people supporting the fact that the couple are living together in a marital relationship. Evidence of bank accounts and so on is also required. If the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is made aware before the application is approved that the marriage has broken down, then the application will be refused. However, once approval has been granted for a change of status on the basis of this marriage, as far as the Department appears to be concerned the matter is closed. If it does come to the notice of the Department after a person has been granted permanent resident status that the relationship has not turned out to be ongoing, there is apparently nothing anybody can or will do. The only way that person can be returned to his country of origin is if he has knowingly not declared an illness or if it is found that he has a criminal record.

What has happened here is that the law as it stands has enabled this man to shirk his responsibilities as a parent, leaving his former wife to return to the country of origin to support and raise the children alone, while he on the other hand settles down to life in a country where presumably there are greater advantages open to him than in the country of his birth. In a way, I suppose, it is a shame that his wife is not to be granted the opportunity to share in those advantages, but I guess this is a double bind for the Government. If she is granted the opportunity to stay and is given permanent resident status, then presumably the man is at liberty to divorce his second wife, remarry the first one, and they both, with the children, have got permanent resident status.

Over the last two financial years 952 overseas students have been granted permanent resident status by reason of marriage. I do not have any available statistics prior to 1986, because they were not computerised until then, but I believe that that is an extraordinary number of students suddenly discovering a romantic attachment that leads to marriage, which then leads to permanent resident status, and that there is no requirement at all for there to be any proof that the relationship was sufficiently bona fide for it to be a lasting one. I do not know what we can do, but it is obviously happening more often than the Government would want. Again I would appreciate it if the Government could take this on board and have a look at some way by which two good systems-our overseas students program and our immigration system-are not joined together and rorted, as is obviously happening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As regards the second matter raised by Senator Haines, I shall certainly ensure that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), as the Minister most immediately responsible for the matters she has expressed concern about, has a copy of the Hansard and any other material Senator Haines may wish to make available. As regards the first matter, which certainly had some difficult elements in it, it is not immediately apparent how one might assist at this stage of the saga.
